properties.Name: Mooney Flat Hotel
properties.Location: In front of private home at 10885 Mooney Flat Rd, one mile north of Hwy 20
properties.Description: Mooney Flat Hotel 1856-1958. Site of the first 3-story team & stage stop on the Henness Pass route to the Northern Mines and Comstock Lode. Built and operated by George and Veronica Schmidt. Served miners, travelers, and teamsters.

properties.Name: Nevada City High School Site
properties.Location: Near sidewalk, across from 626 Zion St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Plaque dedicated by former students: Nevada City High School was located on this site from 1912-1952. This plaque was placed by former students as a lasting memorial to their high school. Note: After merger of Grass Valley and Nevada City high schools, Seven Hills School used the building as a junior high school. In 1973 the buildings were sold to the County of Nevada and eventually torn down. A charter school occupies the adjoining grounds.

properties.Name: Anthony House Site
properties.Location: East side of Pleasant Valley Rd next to dam spillway at Lake Wildwood
properties.Description: Anthony House and Ranch. In 1849, a Mr. Anthony staked out 160 acres on the north side of Deer Creek on the road which would become part of the Marysville-Henness Pass-Virginia City trade route, and built a house and out-buildings. While further details about Mr. Anthony are unknown, the name Anthony House prevailed through a succession of owners. The property was up for sale in 1852 and purchased by Mr. S. P. French. By that time it was a flourishing stage stop, serving as a hotel, restaurant, livery stable and post office. The original house burned down in 1876 but was quickly rebuilt. Subsequent owners included William Henry Davey, Nevada County Supervisor 1908-1916 and later his son, Frank Davey. Stage stop and post office operations continued to 1906 when the post office was moved to Smartsville. Thereafter, declining traffic on the trade route led to farming and cattle raising as the main use of the property. By 1970 when Boise Cascade began development of this area, the property had fallen into disrepair and the house was burned down as a training exercise by the Penn Valley Fire Protection District. Construction of Anthony Dam here on Deer Creek submerged any remains of this historic site under Lake Wildwood.

properties.Name: Felix Gillet
properties.Location: Stone pillar by driveway at intersection of Nursery and Nihell Sts, Nevada City
properties.Description: Here lived and worked Felix Gillet, A Frenchman by birth, an American by adoption from 1871 to 1908 through whose vision and perseverance the horticulture of the world was enriched by the propagation and culture of walnuts, filberts, chestnuts, prunes. In commemoration of his work this tablet was set March 7, 1933 by the WomenÍs Civic Club of Nevada City, California.

properties.Name: Hartung House
properties.Location: 17031 Piper Lane, Penn Valley
properties.Description: In August of 1888 Nevada and Emma (Schwartz) Hartung purchased about 220 acres bordering Pleasant Valley Rd. and Piper Lane in Pleasant Valley (now Penn Valley). At the time of purchase, a small house and a barn were on the property. These two structures likely were built in the early 1860s when the property was owned by James and Hannah Saxon. The first house, still standing in the 1930’s, had deteriorated and was razed. The well, located in the front porch of the house remains. The barn now extended on both ends, still exists. The Hartungs built the current house in 1889. Pear, apple and walnut crops became the primary means of support for the family. A few of the original pear trees remain. Nevada August Hartung was born in August 1853 on the shores of Webber Lake, California in a wagon train on the family's way west from Illinois. It is reported that Nevada's given name was the result of the parents’ awe at their first sight of the Sierra Nevada Mountains. He grew up on his father Adolph Hartung's farm at Kentucky Flat and married Emma Schwartz in 1880. By the time of their 1888 purchase of the property, the Hartungs had three children, Frank (b.1880), Herman (b. 1884) and Mamie (b. 1886). The Hartungs bought the farm from Samuel and Agnes Yeo (owners 1888-1888) and prior to that the property was owned by Joseph Peers (1886-1888) and the Saxons (ca.1860-1886). In 1849-1850, John Rose and William Reynolds operated a trading post and cattle corral, both thought to be located on what became the Hartung property. The current owner, Pete Brennan, acquired the property in 1971 and operates a horse boarding facility.

properties.Name: Naffziger House
properties.Location: 216 Nevada St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Boyhood Home of Howard Christian Naffziger. 1884  M.D., F.A.C.S. 1961. World-renowned neurosurgeon. Professor of surgery, Chief of Surgery and Neurosurgery at University of California Medical School; and Regent of the University of California. House built in 1859 by J. H. Helms. Note: James Harvey Helm (not "Helms") was a City Trustee and operated the Empire Livery Stable on Broad Street.

properties.Name: Bridgeport Covered Bridge
properties.Location: Pleasant Valley Rd at South Fork of Yuba River
properties.Description: This covered bridge across the South Fork of the Yuba River at Bridgeport, Nevada County. Built in 1862 by David Isaac John Wood with lumber from his mill in Sierra County, this bridge was part of the Virginia Turnpike Company Toll Road which served the Northern Mines and the busy Nevada Comstock Lode. Utilizing a combination truss and arch construction, it is one of the oldest housed spans in the West and the longest single span, wooden covered bridge in the United States.The plaque is dedicated to those pioneer Americans who came to California in search of a new life and passed this way to establish their homes in the Northern Mine country. Note: The second plaque is full of errors. Bridgeport originally was known as "Nye's Landing" because Urias and Manuel Nye built a trading post here in 1849, but "Nye's Crossing" was on the Middle Fork of the Yuba River, near the mouth of Oregon Creek. Furthermore, the builder's name was David Ingerfield John Wood.

properties.Name: First Long Distance Telephone
properties.Location: In front of private home at 20342 Pleasant Valley Rd, four m. west of Hwy 49
properties.Description: Built in 1877, the Ridge Telephone Co., connected French Corral with French Lake 58 miles away. It was operated by the Milton Mining Co., from this building which was built about 1853. This plaque donated by Sadie Winn Brainard. Note: This plaque was originally placed on the brick building in which the telephone office was located. After the building was razed in 1955 it was placed on a concrete monument on the shoulder of the present Pleasant Valley Road in front of a neighboring residence. The 1877 date is an error. The line began operation in 1878. The claim of being the "world's first" is still being debated. However, its challengers did not have the track record of the Ridge Telephone Company, which operated successfully into the 20th century over a much longer distance.

properties.Name: Rough and Ready Town Site
properties.Location: Rough and Ready Hwy, corner Chapel Rd, Rough and Ready
properties.Description: Rough and Ready. Established In 1849, and named after the Rough and Ready Company of miners from Wisconsin, in honor of General Zachary Taylor, this was one of the principal towns of Nevada County. Here in 1850, articles of secession were drawn up establishing the 'Republic of Rough and Ready.' As a result of disastrous fires, only a few structures remain today of those built in the 1850s.

properties.Name: Fippin's Blacksmith Shop
properties.Location: 14482 Rough and Ready Hwy, Rough and Ready
properties.Description: Republic of Rough and Ready April 1850 - July 1850. This community of 3000 people seceded from the Union to declare a free and independent state. Colonel E. F. Brundage was elected president. Congressional action on California statehood was pending at the time. Built in the mid 1850s by John Fippin and John Single. Fippin married Single's daughter Julia in 1867, and they raised 10 children. Local legend has it that one of Lotta Crabtree's earliest performances was atop the anvil here. The building today is a combination of the original blacksmith shop and Single's carpenter shop. W. H. (Bill) Fippin and Frank A. Fippin followed their father as smiths and ran the business until well into the 20th century. Members of the Fippin and Single families have served Rough and Ready for generations as County officials, School Trustees and Postmasters.

properties.Name: Rough and Ready Toll House
properties.Location: 14365 Old Rough and Ready Hwy, Rough and Ready
properties.Description: This house and the adjacent property contain five plaques. First plaque: Built in 1859 by Benoni Thompson to collect tolls for using the Gephardt Union Turnpike running 6 miles from Penn Valley to Grass Valley. The last remaining original toll house in the West. It served as a Wells Fargo Express office and stage stop, and was the secret rendezvous place of Joaquin Murietta and Lola Montez. [Note: The reference to Joaquin Murietta and Lola Montez must be taken with a grain of salt and credited to the droll humor of E Clampus Vitus. There is no evidence of such a friendship, although anything was possible in the Old West.]

properties.Name: Rough and Ready Schoolhouse Site
properties.Location: 10079 Blue Creek Rd, south side of Old Rough and Ready Hwy, opposite Cemetery entrance
properties.Description: Note: Present owner requests privacy. Landmark: The original one-room Rough and Ready school was built in 1868. It served the community for many generations before being destroyed in the Trauner Fire of 1994. The house Kevin and Gaylene Collins built here in 1995 has an exterior like that of the schoolhouse.

properties.Name: Toll Road Stake
properties.Location: 14365 Old Rough and Ready Hwy, Rough and Ready
properties.Description: Second Plaque: Toll Road Stake. Across the street from this location is a tree stump in which the original stake exists that was used to close off the passage to travelers from Grass Valley to Penn Valley. Drivers who frequented this road had to stop at this location and pay the toll. Once appropriate compensation was provided, the gate would be opened to allow passage.

properties.Name: China Wall
properties.Location: 14365 Old Rough and Ready Hwy, Rough and Ready
properties.Description: Third plaque: The China Wall. In the 1850s, Chinese laborers, who were an essential part of the community, built the wall you see before you. Large natural stones were hand stacked for its construction. The wall extends 5 miles in either direction, however much of it has disintegrated over the years. This lot, along with the lot across the Gephardt's Union Turnpike, and the adjoining lots, are referred to in the Nevada County tax records as the ïChina LotsÍ as evidence of their history.

properties.Name: Rowe Saw Mill
properties.Location: 14365 Old Rough and Ready Hwy, Rough and Ready
properties.Description: Fourth plaque: Rowe Saw Mill. In the 1860s there were four saw mills in this area. This display, in honor of his founding fathers, is from the Tom Rowe Saw Mill, and displays how the mill works. The foreman stood in the cage and called out the beam size (8x8, 12x12, etc.) then the cutter set the blade which was on a track, and rode the blade down the track until the beam cut was complete. The beam then went to the mines to build the shafts.

properties.Name: Indian Grinding Rock
properties.Location: 14365 Old Rough and Ready Hwy, Rough and Ready
properties.Description: Fifth plaque: Indian Grinding Rock. Indian women used grinding rocks such as these, along with a linear rock called a ïpestleÍ to grind grass seeds, acorns and other foods during the meal preparation process, which included gathering, storing, leaching and cooking. It is believed each hole here served as many as three people, and the six holes here represent the possibility that this encampment contain 18 people total. Acorns, grass seeds and roots provided a diet rich in starch and fat. These Indians were nicknamed the ïDigger IndiansÍ by the local immigrants.

properties.Name: North Star Mine Powerhouse and Nevada County Traction Company
properties.Location: Allison Ranch Rd at McCourtney Rd, Grass Valley
properties.Description: The North Star Powerhouse, built by A. D. Foote in 1895, was the first complete water powered compressed air transmission plant of its kind. Compressed air, generated by Pelton water wheels, furnished power for the entire mine operation. The 30-foot Pelton wheel was the largest in the world, and was in continuous use for over 30 years.Second plaque dedicated 1991 by American Society of Mechanical Engineers: International Mechanical Engineering Heritage Collection Pelton Water Wheel Collection North Star Power House Museum. The Pelton Wheel uses the momentum of a water jet impinging on buckets attached to the periphery of a wheel to produce power. It is a development of the primitive, so-called 'Hurdy Gurdy' wheel used in the California goldfields in the nineteenth century. Various inventors have contributed this type of water turbine, including Lester A. Pelton (1831-1908), who in 1880 patented the characteristic split bucket form. Subsequent important contributions to Pelton-Wheel technology were made by W. A. Doble. This collection illustrates the origin and development of the Pelton Waterwheel. American Society of Mechanical Engineers-1991.Third plaque dedicated 1997 by Historical Society near smaller wheel: Pelton Type Water Wheel. Produced 71000 hp at 327 rpm, diameter 10 ft. Weight 26,000 lbs. Built by Allis Chalmers of single cast nickel steel. Gift of Oroville-Wyandotte Irrigation Dist.  Note: The building presently houses the Historical Society's Mining Museum.

properties.Name: Idaho Maryland Core Sample
properties.Location: Nevada County Fairgrounds, McCourtney Rd, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Plaque dedicated 1961 by Historical Society: Core - Weight 11 Tons. Portion taken from Idaho Shaft No. 2 bored to a vertical depth of 1,125 feet, diameter of shaft five feet, the core boring barrel was invention of J. B. Newsom, mining engineer. Was used as an experiment by the Idaho Maryland Mine Corporation under general manager Errol MacBoyle. With the cooperation of the directors of the 17th District Agricultural Association, through their manager, Malcolm E. Hammill, this core was erected in July 1961. Note: The Newsom drilling machine bored a round shaft, using no explosives. It was cheaper because no timbering was needed. Similar cores are displayed at Calanan Park and Empire Mine Park.

properties.Name: North Star House
properties.Location: 12075 Old Auburn Rd, Grass Valley
properties.Description: This 1905 structure was built for Arthur D. Foote, manager of the North Star mine from 1895 to 1913, and his wife, Mary Hallock Foote, a noted 19th-century author and illustrator. The structure was designed by Julia Morgan, California’s first licensed female architect and designer of the Hearst properties at San Simeon, Asilomar in Pacific Grove, and numerous buildings on the U. C. Berkeley campus, and in total, over 700 buildings. The property is representative of the era that brought Nevada County to the forefront of gold production in California.

properties.Name: Old Auburn Road Bridge (Site)
properties.Location: Old Auburn Rd, southeast of modern bridge over Wolf Creek about 4 m. south of McCourtney Rd
properties.Description: The Old Auburn Bridge was registered as a landmark in 1996 by Nevada County. The bridge consisted of a single span, pin-connected steel pony truss, 66-feet in length, 11-feet in width, with a timber deck carrying a single traffic lane. It was built in 1897 by Cotton Brothers and Co. of Oakland, California. In 2004, the old bridge was dismantled by the County as unsafe and replaced by a modern span. Recognizing the historical significance of the spot, the County erected a monument containing a bronze plaque: Historic Marker Perrin Crossing. This bridge replaces the original steel truss span constructed in 1897 and remained in continuous service until 2004. This crossing received its name from Joseph and Susan Perrin, who settled nearby in 1851. Close to this crossing the Perrin family operated a stagecoach stop known for its hospitality. This road was part of the original stagecoach route between Sacramento and Grass Valley. Note: Remains of the stagecoach stop can be seen about 100 ft. south of the monument

properties.Name: Wolf Post Office
properties.Location: 12582 Garden Bar Rd, Grass Valley
properties.Description: The Nevada County Historical Landmarks Commission is pleased to announce the installation and dedication of a plaque honoring the Wolf Post Office on Sunday, October 6, 2019. Ranchers and farmers began to settle the historic agricultural community of Wolf in the 1860s. William Sweet arrived in Wolf in 1869, immigrating from Cornwall, and purchased 200 acres before his wife and children joined him in 1871. On August 24, 1888, a post office was established for the growing population of Wolf. John Sweet, one of William’s sons, ran the post office from the living room of his ranch house and it soon became a community center and gathering place for approximately 75 residents of Wolf. It is believed that John Sweet was the longest serving U.S. Postmaster, continually running the Wolf Post Office for 52 years until his nephew W. B. Sweet took over on February 19, 1940. W. B. moved the Post Office from his uncle’s home to a small building close by and served the Wolf community until 1956 when the post office was decommissioned with only 2 residents utilizing the service.

properties.Name: Overland Emigrant Trail--Highway 49
properties.Location: Hwy 49 south of Grass Valley, 1.2 m. north of Combie Rd between Clivus Dr and Brewer Rd at South Wolf Creek bridge
properties.Description: At this point, the old Overland Emigrant Trail approaches the present highway. More than 100-years ago it resounded to the creaking wheels of pioneer wagons and the cry of hardy but footsore travelers buoyed by the realization that their long trip to the goldfields was about over.

properties.Name: Root Cellar on Mexican War Land Grant
properties.Location: 16330 Gibboney Lane, Grass Valley. Take Hwy 49 to Alta Sierra intersection and follow Alta Sierra Dr to Gibboney Lane
properties.Description: This old root cellar is located on property that originally was part of a Land Grant of 160 acres granted to Josiah Dodge by President Ulysses Grant in 1873 as Bounty Land for his service as a private with Captain Steen's Co., 1st U.S. Dragoons, War with Mexico. In 1878 this property became part of the John Bree Ranch. The root cellar, built by Bree in the 1880s, was used to store his produce. Mr. Bree was among the first in the county to plant a Bartlett Pear orchard for commercial purposes.

properties.Name: Empire Mine
properties.Location: Empire Mine State Historic Park, 338 E. Empire St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: This plaque marks the site of the Empire Mine, noted for its continuous operation 1850-1957 producing over $120,000,000 in gold.

properties.Name: Chicago Park Historic Agricultural Community
properties.Location: Along Hwy 174 between the Bear River and Brunswick Rd
properties.Description: The Chicago Park Historic Agricultural Community occupies roughly the area on either side of Highway 174 between the Bear River and Brunswick Road. It is centered on the villages of Chicago Park and Peardale. Prior to the 1840s, this area was populated by the Nisenan. In August 1849, what is reported to have been Nevada County's second store was erected on land overlooking the junction of the Bear River and Greenhorn Creek. In the 1850s, local residents led by Simmon Storms succeeded in having the Nisenan removed to a reservation near Tehama. During that period, Benjamin Taylor settled on a ranch in the area which he named Buena Vista, after the Mexican War battle in which he had participated, and engaged in farming and horse breeding. Others who settled in the area found it very suitable for growing fruit, especially pears.In 1872, the Coleman Brothers purchased the Buena Vista and Storms ranches, and other properties in the area, as they were developing the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad. Completed in 1876, the Railroad spurred the agricultural development of the area. In 1887, a group of Colfax and Chicago, Illinois developers acquired several thousand acres of land and drew up plans for the Chicago Park Colony. The Colony was to consist of 20 and 40 acre tracts as well as town lots laid out around a public square with streets named for prominent streets in Chicago. Much of the planned development never materialized, but reportedly almost 7000 acres were sold, principally to residents of Chicago. Many of the tracts were planted with orchards, and the area was referred to as the Bartlett Pear Belt. The railroad station at Storms Station was renamed Chicago Park Station, There were also stations at Buena Vista and Peardale. Fruit was king in the area for about 100-years. Orchards growing pears, plums, peaches and apples were everywhere. Because water was not abundant, dry farming techniques were mastered which improved fruit color. In 1915, local Bartlett pears were honored at the Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco. As the 20th century progressed, pear blight appeared, causing some growers to switch to other crops.

properties.Name: Rollins Dam and Reservoir
properties.Location: Larsen Rd about 1000 ft from Orchard Springs access road to Rollins Lake, Chicago Park
properties.Description: Two plaques dedicated 1966 by Nevada Irrigation District:  "Nevada Irrigation District, Yuba-Bear River Development, Rollins Dam & Reservoir Completed 1965.” "To all those individuals and agencies whose foresight, labors and support made possible the construction of this project and the benefits the entire region derives from its features."

properties.Name: Old Pacific Fruit Packing Shed
properties.Location: Mount Olive and Lower Colfax Rds, Chicago Park
properties.Description: A smaller shed, built here in 1926, collapsed during a snowstorm in 1929. Its successor was built in 1930 by the Civilian Conservation Corps. The Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad tracks, depot, and water tower were alongside this building, where peaches and pears from the surrounding orchards were packed and sent to Colfax by train. There the boxes were transferred to standard sized refrigerator freight cars to be shipped to the East.

properties.Name: Saint Paul Lutheran Church Site
properties.Location: St. Paul Pl. east of Hwy 174 at Chicago Park. St. Paul Cemetery is first left past the fire station
properties.Description: On this site donated by Anna Pusheck the German Evangelical Lutheran St. Paul congregation was established in 1902 for worship and praise to God, continuing until 1984. Note: Anna Pusheck was the mother of Dr. Charles Pusheck, one of the Chicago Park Colony's developers. In 1895, he built a sanitorium in Chicago Park, which he later converted to a hotel. The St. Paul Lutheran church building was dedicated in December 1904. After the church was destroyed by fire on MotherÍs Day 1971, services were held in the parsonage until 1984. Most services and record keeping were in the German language until 1924. From then until 1942 both English and German were used to compile important data, and English services were held once a month. An English-language hymnal was used for the first time on September 28, 1924. After the outbreak of World War II the use of German was discontinued altogether.

properties.Name: You Bet Town Site
properties.Location: Red Dog Rd, between Lowell Hill and Chalk Bluff Rds, six m. east of You Bet Rd exit on Hwy 174
properties.Description: This mining camp, established between 1858-1860, consisted of 40 or 50 buildings by 1864. A school house was built midway between You Bet and Red Dog. The town was destroyed by fire in April 1869, partially rebuilt, and burned again in September 1873 and August 1915. The courts halted most hydraulic mining in 1884, but gold mining continued until the 1940s. The You Bet Post Office was closed in 1903.

properties.Name: Red Dog Town Site
properties.Location: Red Dog Rd, 3 m. north of You Bet Rd intersection. 0.5 m. southeast of Greenhorn Creek
properties.Description: Note: The site is a federally restricted area. Red Dog (1851-1871), with a population of 2,000 at its peak, was the third town of importance in Nevada County, surviving longer than most of the earliest gold towns. The Post Office closed in 1869.

properties.Name: Old Bear River Bridge
properties.Location: Hwy 174 at Bear River, between Colfax and Chicago Park
properties.Description: Since 1852 bridges near this site have served as the gateway to western Nevada County. This 1924 span was the first concrete bridge at this site and features a Roman style single arch design, constructed in a continuous pour method. The Colfax Highway Association led a citizens group that saved the bridge from the wrecker’s ball in 1986, and placed this monument in 1992.

properties.Name: Veterans Memorial Flagstaffs, Grass Valley
properties.Location: Entrances to Greenwood and Catholic cemeteries, W. Main St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Plaques and flagstaffs dedicated 1954 by Post 130, American Legion Auxiliary: Lest We Forget. This memorial flagstaff dedicated in eternal memory of those war veterans resting within the portals of this cemetery who served in the wars of our nation and those who gave their lives defending AmericaÍs eternal freedoms.

properties.Name: Gilmore Flying Field
properties.Location: Lyman Gilmore School, corner Gilmore Way and W. Main St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Gilmore Flying Field. This windsock marks the site of one of the first flying fields in the United States. Here Lyman Gilmore, a contemporary of the Wright Brothers, pioneered in aviation by designing and building his own planes and gliders as early as 1898. Plaque on monument in front of school dedicated 1968 by Grand Lodge, Free and Accepted Masons: Lyman Gilmore, Jr. 1874-1951. Lyman Gilmore, Jr. established the first commercial airport on this site in 1907. To him and his memory the people of this community dedicate this school as the Lyman Gilmore School. Note: Gilmore did not use this field until the winter of 1911-12. As the Daily Transcript reported on January 29, 1912, "The principal place of business [of the Gilmore Airship Co.] was recently moved from Colfax to Grass Valley, and the meeting on Saturday evening was the first with the present board of directors." This pole was used originally at Gilmore Field, which Gilmore always claimed was the first commercial airport on the West Coast. The CETA mural on the north wall of the multipurpose building was painted in 1978.

properties.Name: Glasson House
properties.Location: 515 W. Main St. Grass Valley
properties.Description: This Victorian/Greek Revival house was built in 1866 for Miles P. O'Connor, who came to California in 1849 and to Nevada County in 1852. He served as justice of the peace for Little York township in 1852-53 and for Grass Valley 1862-69. He served one term in the state assembly and two in the state senate. He earned a fortune from the famous Idaho gold mine and was instrumental in creation of the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad. After selling this house to John Polglase in 1873, he moved to San Jose and funded various institutions, including a sanitarium later known as O'Connor Hospital. John Polglase, a hard-rock miner from Cornwall, came to Grass Valley in 1864. In 1875 Polglase bought an interest in John Glasson's grocery and provisions store while continuing to work underground in the Idaho mine. In 1882 he sold the house to his partner, and Glasson and his heirs owned it from then until 1973. John Glasson, like Polglase, came here in 1864 from England, and like O'Connor he played a prominent role in Nevada County history. He bought the local gas company in 1885-86 and in 1888 merged it with the Grass Valley Electric Light and Motor Co. He built the countyÍs first hydroelectric plant at Deer Creek Falls and was a director and treasurer of the Narrow Gauge railroad. His daughter Bernice was a major benefactor to the Sierra Nevada Memorial Hospital, and she lived in this house until her death in 1966.

properties.Name: Holbrooke Hotel
properties.Location: 212 W. Main St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Holbrooke Hotel Founded 1851. California’s oldest hotel in continuous operation. Among its century-old archives are names of such notables as Presidents Grant, Harrison, Cleveland; authors Mark Twain, Bret Harte; boxers Corbett, Fitzsimmons; actor Gilbert Barry, and highwayman Black Bart. Present structure built in 1862 following infamous fire.Landmark registered and second plaque dedicated 1978 by State of California, CHL 914: ñThe present bar of the hotel has been in continuous operation since 1852, when it was known as the Golden Gate Saloon. The wooden building had a rear extension called The Exchange Hotel and offered food and lodging by January 1853. The saloon was destroyed in the fire of 1855 and rebuilt out of fieldstone with a brick front. The Holbrooke, built in 1862, had the adjacent Golden Gate Saloon incorporated in the hotel building.Third plaque dedicated by Grass Valley Downtown Association: Presidential Square. These Presidents of the United States have visited this site: Ulysses S. Grant, James A. Garfield, Benjamin Harrison, Grover Cleveland, Herbert Hoover.  Note: No evidence exists that some of these notables stayed at the Holbrooke or visited Grass Valley.  Local lore has it that Gilbert Barry is a Clamper fabrication.

properties.Name: Williams Stationery Store
properties.Location: 112 W. Main St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: This building is known as 'The Brick Store of Silvester and Salaman‰' it was built in 1854 and completed in 1855 by Henry Silvester and Abraham Salaman. It is both the first and oldest original brick (and stone) building in Grass Valley and the second oldest brick building in Nevada County. There have only been three owners of this building, Henry Sylvester, Paul Wesley Michell, and Elton and Helen Williams. Only five businesses have occupied the store in 145 years, H. Silvester Grocery, H. J. Fuchs Grocery, C. W. Jenkin Variety Store, Tresize Brothers Stationery Store, Williams Brothers, later changed to Williams Stationery Store.

properties.Name: Binkelmann Brewery
properties.Location: 217 N. Auburn St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Born in Wurtemberg, Germany on January 2, 1828, David Binkelmann came to Grass Valley in 1853 after only a year as a new immigrant in New York. He mined for a time on Wolf Creek, then worked in a bakery. He became a renter of the business, but after two years sold the bakery operation to Herrman Maurer and bought a half-interest in a brewery with John Frank, operating in the rear of the Western Hotel which burned in 1856. The brick brewery was constructed in 1861, replacing a smaller 1856 frame building on North Auburn Street. Frank Richard bought out the partner in 1861 and was in turn bought out by Binkelmann shortly later. He ran the brewery until his death on May 23, 1894, leaving his wife Sophie to carry on until her death in 1915, when the brewery was bequeathed to her son, David J. Binkelmann. Note: The Brewery building, which has a beautiful vaulted brick cellar, has been incorporated into the hotel across the street.

properties.Name: Washington Brewery
properties.Location: 114 E Main St Grass Valley
properties.Description: Founded 1858 by John Frank, the brewery operated until prohibition. The ownership remains in the Frank family to the present time. Note: The Frank family sold the building in 1973. It no longer functions as a brewery.

properties.Name: Red Ledge Stamp Mill
properties.Location: Corner of Main and Auburn Sts, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Stamp Mill. This three stamp mill was donated to the City of Grass Valley by Mrs. Stella Tracy, owner of the famous Red Ledge Mine near Washington, Nevada County, where this mill crushed tons of gold bearing ore for many years. It is erected here in memory of the 'Cousin Jack' miners who came from Cornwall, England with their knowledge of hardrock mining used to bring gold bearing quartz to the surface from the deep mines of the area.

properties.Name: Dr. W. C. Jones Home Site
properties.Location: 129 S Auburn St, now Grass Valley Police Dept
properties.Description: Dr. W. C. Jones came to Grass Valley in 1874 after serving as physician and surgeon for the Central Pacific Railroad Co. during construction of the railroad between Colfax and Reno. He had three sons, Will, John, and Carl, who along with their father served the community as doctors until the last son died in 1944. In 1904 Dr. John Jones opened the first private hospital in Nevada County-the W. C. Jones Memorial Hospital, Grass Valley. A fourth son, George, became Superior Court Judge of Nevada County, serving from 1908 until 1925 and again from 1938 until he retired in 1947. Note: The city removed the historic house to make room for the police department.

properties.Name: Chinatown Grass Valley (Site)
properties.Location: Corner of Tinloy and Bank Sts, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Chinatown, Grass Valley 1850-1938. Of the many gold rush Immigrants the Chinese were noted for their honest, sober and industrious characteristics. Each mining camp had its Chinatown and Grass Valley was second only to San FranciscoÍs. Former residents Duck Egg, Georgie Bow, Ah Louie, and the pioneer Yuen, Gon and Tinloy families are an integral part of Nevada County’s history. Note: Georgie Bow went to China, where he was in the diplomatic service. Chinatown was torn down in 1939 to make way for a truck terminal. Now the site is occupied by a hotel and parking lot.

properties.Name: Grass Valley Hardware
properties.Location: 114 and 116 Mill St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Plaque dedicated 1969 by Native Daughters and Native Sons of the Golden West: Through the years of prospecting hydraulic and hardrock mining this hardware business, one of CaliforniaÍs oldest, has served the community. In continuous operation at this site since 1854.

properties.Name: Edward Coleman House
properties.Location: 318 Neal St, corner School St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: The Edward Coleman House. Edward Coleman built this house in 1866. While residing here, Coleman was President/Superintendent of the Idaho Mine, Director of the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad, and had interests in the Mohawk Lumber Company. Coleman sold this house in 1893.

properties.Name: Caroline Mead Hanson House
properties.Location: 319 Neal St, corner of S. Church St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Homesite of Caroline Mead Hanson. Whose idea sparked the annual Donation Day sponsored by Grass Valley Ladies Relief Society since 1883. Note: Home of the originator of Grass Valley's Donation Day, that began In 1883. Mrs. Hansen, an invalid, sat in the bay window of her home and watched the children troop to school. Hearing of the Ladies Relief SocietyÍs shortage of funds she suggested a plan to help the needy share the Feast of Christmas. Each child would bring a stick of wood and a potato to school on the same day named by the school superintendent. The potatoes would be put in a sack provided by the janitor; the wood would be piled in the school yard. On the following day these donations would be removed by the Relief Society and dispensed as needed. Mrs. Hansen conveyed her plan in a letter to the Grass Valley Daily Union that was published November 20, 1883. Since that date thousands of Grass Valley school children and citizens have marched in the Donation Day parade.

properties.Name: Grass Valley's Famed Maple
properties.Location: Neal St, in private yard at corner of School St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: This beautiful, Brandywine Maple, subject for artists and photographers, was brought from the fields of Gettysburg, and planted in 1876 by the widow of the poet and editor of the Grass Valley National newspaper, John Rollin Ridge. Surviving the fire which leveled the home, it now adorns the lovely Victorian home built by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Clinch in 1900. Roy Clinch Tremoureux, grandson, notes proudly that many trees which beautify our town have come from this famed maple. Note: Time has ravaged the maple.

properties.Name: Bell Hill School Bell
properties.Location: Bell Hill School, 342 S. School St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: The Bell Hill School Bell 1877. This school bell is lovingly dedicated to the children and teachers of the Grass Valley School District who daily answered its melodious tone. The bell was cast at the Buckeye Bell Foundry in Cincinnati by Vanduzen and Tift, and the rotary yoke was patented in 1868. The bell was placed in this beautiful monument by Harold J. Perry, a member of the Grass Valley Host Lions Club. Dedicated March 30,1985 as a part of the 100th Anniversary Celebration of Quartz Parlor No. 58.

properties.Name: Mt. Saint Mary's Convent and Academy
properties.Location: 400 S. Church St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Mt. St. Mary's School. To this spot Father Thomas J. Dalton brought the Sisters of Mercy in 1863. The Sisters of Mercy have taught here since that date. Landmark registered and second plaque dedicated 1972  Built by the Reverend Thomas J. Dalton and dedicated May 2, 1865 by Bishop Eugene O'Connell as Sacred Heart Convent and Holy Angels Orphanage. Under the Sisters of Mercy it served from 1866 to 1932 as the first orphanage of the Northern Mines. It functioned as an academy (1868-1965) and a convent (1866-1968).

properties.Name: St Patrick's Cemetery
properties.Location: Corner Chapel and Church Sts, Grass Valley
properties.Description: St. Patrick’s Cemetery 1853. In memory of the pioneers buried here. A sign nearby contains this information: Site of the first Catholic Church in Grass Valley. Dedicated on October 25,1853. Rev. John Shanahan, 1st Pastor. Served as church 'till December 5, 1858. Served as the first Catholic School (1859-1879).

properties.Name: Empire House
properties.Location: 535 Mill St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: This site at the lower end of Boston Ravine on the old main road from Grass Valley to Auburn has been the location of a public house since 1851. Charles Behrisch was the owner from 1851 to 1885. Ownership changed hands many times through the years. Purchased by Dominic Pajnich on August 1,1933, and was burned in 1934. Replaced with a 14-room hotel, named Empire Inn. Upstairs closed off in 1964, but remains a popular food and beverage stop today. Boston Ravine, established in 1849, was the earliest mining community in the area which subsequently grew into Grass Valley.

properties.Name: Gold Quartz Discovery
properties.Location: Corner of Jenkins St and Hocking Ave, Grass Valley
properties.Description: This tablet commemorates the discovery of gold-bearing quartz and the beginning of quartz mining in California. The discovery was made on Gold Hill by George McKnight October, 1850 The occurrence of gold-bearing quartz was undoubtedly noted here and elsewhere about the same time, or previously, but the above discovery created the great excitement that started the development of quartz mining into a great industry. The Gold Hill Mine from 1850 to 1857 is credited with a total production of $4,000,000.

properties.Name: Lola Montez House Replica
properties.Location: 284 Mill St Grass Valley
properties.Description: Lola Montez (1819-1861) Countess of Landsfeld. In her home which occupied this site, Lola’s social salons 1853-1855 attracted men of vision whose investments and technology founded Nevada CountyÍs gold quartz mining industry. She brought culture and refinement to this rude mining camp. A mistress of international intrigue and a feminist before her time she is one of history’s most recognizable women and a founder of today’s cosmetic industry. Note: After earlier building was torn down this replica of original house was built. It now houses a small museum. LolaÍs house had been the office of Grass Valley Quartz Mining Co., the first consolidated effort at deep underground mining. Also site of first school in Grass Valley, a private school run by Rosa Farrington in 1851 before she moved to School Street.

properties.Name: Emmanuel Episcopal Church
properties.Location: 235 S. Church St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Historic Emmanuel Episcopal Church. Oldest Episcopal edifice in California. First services April 23, 1854 by Rt. Rev. William I. Kip, Bishop of Calif. This building opened for worship Aug. 1856. Note: The church was declared eligible for National Landmark status in 1982, but the vestry declined to have the church registered. The first services mentioned above were held in "a public hall" according to an account by Bishop Kip. On December 11, 1856, the Gold Hill Mining Company donated land to the parish that was bounded by Church, Walsh and Mill streets. The present church opened for worship in 1858. It is the oldest existing Episcopal Church in continuous use in California.

properties.Name: Crabtree House
properties.Location: 238 Mill St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Lotta Crabtree was born in New York in 1847. In 1852 the gold fever brought Mr. Crabtree to California, and a year later his wife and Lotta followed. Several months after arriving in San Francisco Mrs. Crabtree and Lotta went to Grass Valley and started a boarding house for miners with Mr. Crabtree. It was here that Lotta met Lola Montez, who taught her to sing and dance. Lotta made her first public appearance in Plumas County, which led to a successful career on stage, both here and abroad.

properties.Name: Grass Valley Public Library (Josiah Royce Library)
properties.Location: 207 Mill St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: There are four plaques. First plaque and fir tree dedicated 1931 by Native Daughters and Native Sons of the Golden West: 1854 - Himalayan Fir - 1916. Planted In Memory of Dr. Josiah Royce one of AmericaÍs greatest scholars whose birthplace is the site of this Library. Second plaque dedicated 1933 by the Harvard Club of San Francisco: 1855 - Josiah Royce - 1916. Born in Grass Valley Alumnus of the University of California. Renowned Harvard teacher and eminent American philosopher. Third plaque and maple tree dedicated behind library ca. 1955 by the Harvard Club of San Francisco: Royce Centennial, to the memory of Josiah Royce Born here on November 20,1855. This tree was planted by the Harvard Club of San Francisco Veritas. Fourth plaque dedicated 1992 by the Friends of the Nevada County Libraries: Gift of Carnegie Corporation of New York. Dedicated August 4,1916. Note: The fir tree is now gone. In 2003 the County Board of Supervisors named the library for the renowned philosopher, who had died in 1916, the year in which the Carnegie Library opened its doors.

properties.Name: Dow Alexander Park
properties.Location: Corner Bennett and Bank Sts, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Formerly known as the City Square, this park was established by the Grass Valley Women's Improvement Club in 1911, as a place of rest for patrons of the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad. It was dedicated to the pioneers and veterans of the Spanish American War. Second plaque: Last on duty at Fort Point on San Francisco Bay. Grass Valley Women’s Improvement Club arranged with the US War Department for donation to be placed in City Square, now Dow Alexander Park. Transferred from Benicia Arsenal to here in 1911. Only known example of its type to exist. Weight: 9100 pounds.

properties.Name: Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad (I)
properties.Location: Entrance at Bennett and Bank Sts, Grass Valley. Plaque at Bennett and Kidder Sts.
properties.Description: Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad ran from here 5 miles N to Nevada City and 17 miles S to Colfax. Built 1874-76 by John F. Kidder whose home is NE corner. Depot and shops were 50 yards N., rails removed 1942. Sarah, widow of builder, was first woman R.R. president.

properties.Name: Reliance Hose Company No. 3
properties.Location: Race St near S. Auburn St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: This Building, Housing Reliance Hose Company No. 3 since 1891, is hereby marked for preservation, thus honoring The Volunteer Fire Department of Grass Valley March 26, 1988 100th Anniversary of Manzanita Parlor #29, Native Daughters of the Golden West. Note: Marion Leech Conway's memoirs indicate the building was dedicated in December 1911, after housing the company for twenty years. "The doors of Reliance No. 3 have had the latch string out in welcome greeting to all when the word went out the Reliance would entertain its friends."

properties.Name: World War I Memorial, Grass Valley
properties.Location: Memorial Park, corner of Race St and Colfax Ave, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Plaque dedicated 1921: Honor Roll. Heroes from the Grass Valley District who gave their lives for their country 1917-1918: Anthony J. Bevilacqua, Robert H. Beyer, Lawrence A. Brasher, Melvyn Frandy, Isaac Leslie Fleming, Hedley Hill, Lenville Dooley Jatunn, William Hague, William A. Kneebone, Albert Pinkham, William Hawley Moran, James Rodgers, Clarence Crase Thomas, J. M. Spencer, Elton Thomas Whiting, John Edward White. Recently, a small plaque at the base of the main plaque added U.S. Army Nurse Elina W. Hill to the Honor Roll. Note: The above inscription is on a very large monument. Surrounding it is a grove of 16 trees, each with a marker in front inscribed with the name of one of these men and the American Legion logotype.

properties.Name: World War II & Korean War Memorial
properties.Location: Memorial Park, corner of Race St and Colfax Ave, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Plaque dedicated by Grass Valley Elks No. 538 and Frank Gallino Post No. 130 American Legion: World War II 1941-1946 Korean 1950-1955. To the men and women who made the supreme sacrifice for our country and her noble purpose, in memory of those who died that liberty might live. Note: Plaque is on a concrete monument that includes a flagpole and benches.

properties.Name: Vietnam War Memorials, Grass Valley
properties.Location: Memorial Park, corner of Race St and Colfax Ave, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Plaques dedicated 1966 and 1974 by Hague-Thomas-Hegarty (now Frank Gallino) Post No. 130, American Legion: 1966 plaque: Gary Ames Miller Memorial. This memorial is dedicated to all American servicemen and women of the Vietnam War in the name of Gary Ames Miller, United States Marine Corps, the first local serviceman to give the full measure for God and country in this conflict. All Americans owe an endless debt of gratitude to the gallant men and women of our armed services for preserving our way of life, a life endowed with justice, freedom and democracy.1974 plaque: Western Nevada County servicemen killed in action in Vietnam: Edward Alien Ownry 09/09/65, Gary Ames Miller 06/01/66, Douglas A. Rix 02/28/67, Bruce Allan Jensen 08/27/67, Alan Robert Haugen 04/06/68, Ronald J. Walber 04/25/68, Thomas W. Cranford 05/09/68, Harry Lee Theurkauf 06/12/68, Donald Ray Webb 10/12/68, Ernest James Stidham 12/22/68, John R. Kunkel 01/13/69, Philip A. Tritsch 01/28/69, Kenneth W. Scurr 05/31/69, Michael D. Goeller 06/01/69, David E. Freestone 08/27/69, James Deeble 04/17/70.  Note: These plaques are mounted on a huge drill core.There are also memorial plaques for the following Vietnam veterans located on the following Golden Center Freeway overpasses around Grass Valley.L/Cpl USMC: Gary Ames Miller 12/14/1947-06/01/1966, west end Brunswick RdPvt USA: Thomas W. Cranford 12/09/194-05/09/1968, west end Dorsey DrS/Sgt USA: Douglas A. Rix 10/02/1942-02/28/196, north side Idaho_Maryland RdL/Cpl USMC: John R. Kunkel 04/16/1947-01/13/1969, west side Bennett St1st Lt USA: Kenneth W. Scurr  07/12/1948- 05/31/1969, south side Bank StPfcUSA: David E. Freestone 06/10/1948-08/27/1969, north side Colfax Ave Sp/5 USA: Harry Lee Theurkauf 05/15/1946- 06/12/1968, parking area S. Auburn StCapt USAF: Bruce Alan Jensen-11/18/1928 08/27/1967, east offramp W. Empire St1st Lt USA: Ernest James Stidham:  03/14/1943-12/22/1968, northwest side of the Hwy 20 overpass of Mill St.

properties.Name: Hard Rock Gold Mining
properties.Location: Memorial Park, Grass Valley, near creek by Race St culvert
properties.Description: Hard Rock Gold Mining 1850-1957. Within a one-mile radius of this spot more than 500 million dollars worth of gold was produced by deep mines, including the Empire, North Star and the Idaho-Maryland. During that time this was the worldÍs most concentrated, efficient and innovative gold mining region.

properties.Name: Loutzenheiser Pharmacy Building/Foothill Flowers
properties.Location: 102 W Main St Grass Valley
properties.Description: Operated by pioneer druggist William Loutzenheiser (1824_1905) and son, John G. (1861-1929). The pharmacy begin here in a wooden building in 1851. The structure gave way to the present brick edifice in the fall of 1855. William was a member of the 1861 city Board of Trustees, one of the original locators of the Idaho Quartz claim, and was active in several other mining ventures. On July 4, 1887 the pharmacy was the site of a bloody duel between two Grass Valley merchants, Henry Sylvester and John Davis, in which the latter was killed. In 1928 the business changed hands after 77 years of continuous operation by the Loutzenheiser family. Between 1928 and 1966 the building had many tenants. In the fall of 1966 Marie Johnson, known as the Flower Lady, founded Foothill Flowers. The interior of the building was destroyed by fire in May 1984 and was subsequently remodeled.

properties.Name: Shaar Zedek Grass Valley Jewish Cemetery
properties.Location: Location: Second Street off Eureka Street, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Shaar Zedek, or the Gate of Righteousness, was established in 1856. The first burial was in 1857 and the last in 1891. Thirty headstones are visible. The cemetery was restored around 50 years ago by the Commission for the Preservation of Pioneer Jewish Cemeteries and Landmarks. It is locked and fenced to protect against vandalism.

properties.Name: The Old Post Office
properties.Location: 131 S. Auburn St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: This building Is known as the Old Post Office. It was built in 1914 by the United States Government as the Grass Valley Post Office. From 1914 until 1984 the Post Office functioned for mail, package and gold shipments from the many mines in the area. After the Post Office moved to East Main Street the building operated as an Insurance Agency in the 1980’s and as professional offices since October 1989. Note: Plaque was dedicated in memory of Nevada County pioneer United States Senators Aaron Augustus Sargent (1873-1879) and William Morris Stewart (1865-1875 and 1887-1905).

properties.Name: Grass Valley Masonic Lodge
properties.Location: 126 S Auburn St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Masonry in Grass Valley. Madison Lodge #23 was established under dispensation from the Grand Lodge of California on May 4th 1852. Its permanent charter was issued on May 5th 1853. Madison Lodge held its first two meetings at the old Columbus School on the present site of Hennessy School. The Lodge moved to a building on the south side of Main St.  where it now meets Auburn St.  This wooden building was destroyed along with most of Grass Valley in the great fire of September 12 and 13, 1855. A few days later, the Masons met with the Odd Fellows to select a site for a new brick building to house both organizations at 110 Mill St. This building was Madison's home for nearly 73 years, until fire destroyed the Masonic portion of the building in December 1928. For the next nine years the Lodge met in the auditorium of the old Strand Theater at 161 Mill St.  During this time, planning was being completed for our present building, which saw its first meeting on January 29, 1938. For 150-years, in both good times and bad, through 7 wars and a great depression, the Masonic spirit of Brotherly Love, Relief and Truth has continued on through our brethren of honorable men of all backgrounds, professions and faith. This plaque was set on May 9, 2002 in rededication ceremonies conducted by C. Ray Whitaker, Grand Master of Masons in California and Elmer B. Curtis, Master of Madison Lodge.

properties.Name: Grass Valley Historical District
properties.Location: Downtown Grass Valley
properties.Description: Dedicated in 1969 by the Grass Valley City Planning Commission. Description: A colorful, old gold-mining town established in 1849 at Boston Ravine and later named Grass Valley by a company of emigrants. The atmosphere of early mining days still clings to the town. Significant sites include the Empire Mine State Historic Park, the North Star House and the homes of Lola Montez and Lotta Crabtree.

properties.Name: The Auditorium Building
properties.Location: 161 Mill St, Grass Valley
properties.Description: The Auditorium Building. On July 30, 1896, a fire started here at the site of Argall’s Opera House, owned by Charles E. Clinch, burning the entire block on East Mill Street from Neal to Bank. In 1900, an incorporation composed of the Native Sons of the Golden West, Ancient Order of the Foresters, Knights of Pythias, Red Men, and the Miner’s Union was formed to build a fine theater of three stories. The first floor held a magnificent theater with a capacity of 600 on the floor and 250 in the gallery and office space for the Grass Valley City Hall. The second story was devoted to lodge rooms and the third story was a banquet hall. The basement housed both the kitchen and the armory for Company 1 of the National Guard. On February 2, 1901, the Auditorium Theater opened to a week-long celebration and operated until November 12, 1922. Two days later, it reopened as the Strand Movie Theater, operating until April 22, 1942. The building was then home of the F. S. Rasco & Co. store and since 1972 has been home to Hedman/Ashley furniture store.

properties.Name: Woman's Christian Temperance Union
properties.Location: North side of Neal St between Mill and S. Church Sts, Grass Valley
properties.Description: The first Woman's Christian Temperance Union in California organized in Grass Valley March 25, 1874. Rededicated and second plaque placed 2014: Originally placed near the corner of Neal and South Church Streets near the site of the old Congregational Church and the Women's Improvement Club building. Note: In 1972, the Congregational Church building was demolished to make way for a bank building. The first plaque was removed and stored in the nearby Methodist Church. In 2014, it was rededicated by the Manzanita Parlor of the Native Daughters at its present location on a monument constructed from petrified wood.

properties.Name: Memorial Park GV
properties.Location: Memorial Park, corner of Race St and Colfax Ave, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Memorial Park was built in 1921 in memory of local armed forces members who died in World War I. The land and swimming pool were donated by the Empire Mine Co.; the club house was donated by the Idaho Maryland Mine Co.; and people of the area subscribed $8,000.  It now contains five plaques honoring those who served our country in the armed forces.

properties.Name: Marines Memorial
properties.Location: Memorial Park, corner of Race St and Colfax Ave, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Plaque dedicated 2003 by Marine Corps League Gold Country Detachment 885: "These memorials honor those who served in the Armed Forces of the United States of America. For those who returned, thank you God. For those who died, glory forever God. For those still missing, please God."

properties.Name: Pioneers Memorial
properties.Location: Memorial Park, corner of Race St and Colfax Ave, Grass Valley
properties.Description: Plaque  dedicated 1929 by Native Daughters  of the Golden West: In memory of our pioneer mothers & fathers dedicated June 12, 1929 by Manzanita Parlor No  29 N.D.G.W.

properties.Name: Nevada County Narrow Gauge (III)
properties.Location: Railroad Ave at back entrance to Northern Queen Inn, Nevada City
properties.Description: For 66 years, the Nevada City depot served as the northern terminus for the railroad affectionately known as the 'Never Come Never Go.' In 1874 a group of 7 men, led by lumber mill and gold mine owner John C. Coleman, organized the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad. Engineer John Flint Kidder was hired on January 14, 1875 to build a 23-mile narrow gauge railroad from the Central Pacific Railroad connection in Colfax to Grass Valley and Nevada City. On a snowy May 20, 1876, John Coleman drove the last spike in Nevada City to dedicate the completion of the railroad. John Kidder controlled the railroad from January 1884, until his death on April 10, 1901; the following day, his widow Sara was elected president of the railroad. Sara Kidder successfully managed the company until its sale on April 24, 1913 to the Oakland, Antioch and Eastern, a predecessor to the Western Pacific. On May 13, 1926, the N.C.N.G.R.R. was purchased by a group of local investors and it operated until December 1942. The scrapping of the railroad was completed by May 5,1943. Two other plaques at this location were dedicated on June 11,1994, but cannot presently be located.Text of second plaque: In fond appreciation of the known surviving employees of the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad Co. 1876-1942. Bob Paine, Tony Dellea, Sadie Angelini, Eugene Katzer, Homer Bevared, George Jefferson, Edward Smith, Bill Tremewan.Text of third plaque: In grateful appreciation to the Northern Queen Inn and the Ramey family for their dedicated efforts in the restoration and preservation of Nevada County’s railroad history.

properties.Name: Glenbrook Basin
properties.Location: Sutton Way, south of Brunswick Rd, next to bus shelter in Glenbrook Plaza parking lot
properties.Description: Early In the 1850's Glenbrook Basin first became known as the site of county fairs, horse racing and other special events. When Olympia Park, located at the south end of the basin, opened in 1901, Glenbrook Basin became the recreational center of Nevada County and much of Northern California, and remained so for over fifty years. People would come to the basin by horse and buggy or later the automobile, but those wishing for a little more excitement would often use the Nevada County Traction Company’s trolley, or the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad. The large grandstands of the three-quarter-mile racetrack stood near the junction of present Brunswick Road and Sutton Way. Trotting, pacing, and running horse races were held at the track, and motor car races began in 1913. The racetrack was one of the first electrically lighted racetracks in the state. A dam was constructed just northeast of the existing electrical substation to form Lake Olympia. The lake soon became one of the BasinÍs main attractions. Located in the center of Lake Olympia was an island with a pavilion which had a coil-spring-mounted dance floor that swayed with the rhythm of the dancers' feet. There was swimming, boating and fishing in Lake Olympia, and during some winters there was ice skating. There were boats and bathing suits for rent, and the park contained a bathhouse, a roller skating rink, and a bar. Many a romance blossomed on the lake during an evening boat ride under the stars. Families rented cabins and picnicked in the shade of the large pine trees along the shores of Lake Olympia. Olympia Park was the site of high school commencements, football and baseball games, and special events such as fat ladies' races and freckled-face children contests. The annual miners' picnics were held at the park with mucking and drilling contests, tug-of-wars and Cornish wrestling, as refreshments of various kinds flowed freely. Olympia Park fell into disrepair in the 1950s and ceased operation in 1958. Glenbrook Basin, once the recreational center for Nevada County, has developed into one of the countyÍs main centers of commerce in supplying various types of shopping, restaurants, services and recreation for the residents and visitors of Nevada County.

properties.Name: The Union Newspaper
properties.Location: 11464 Sutton Way, Grass Valley, in the Glenbrook Basin
properties.Description: Of the many historic newspapers started in the Northern Mines of the great Mother Lode during the famous gold rush era, only The Union of Grass Valley and Nevada City emerged a successful daily published for 100 years. Born in critical times: Civil War and presidential election. The Union has ever strived for unity and has evolved an independent voice supporting man and measure over partisanship. The Union is only the seventh daily newspaper in California to celebrate its Centennial under the original name. Centennial Date, October 28, 1964. Plaque dedicated when The Union newspaper was located on Mill Street, Grass Valley and moved with the newspaper to Sutton Way in December 1978.

properties.Name: Idaho-Maryland Mine Site
properties.Location: Hillside adjacent to Centennial Dr and Whispering Pines Lane, south of Idaho Maryland Rd, Grass Valley
properties.Description: The Idaho quartz mine was discovered in 1863. It prospered under the Coleman brothers from 1867-93, then consolidated with the Maryland and other small mines. Eventually it became one of the 'Big Three' of the Northern Mines, the other two being the Empire and the North Star. Its final years under the management of Errol MacBoyle were very productive. He developed a revolutionary method of shaft sinking, using a huge core drill called the Newsom drilling machine. World War II and government order L208 brought about final closing. Note: Various parts of the mine still exist. The office building is off the east side of Centennial Drive, between Idaho Maryland Road and Whispering Pines Lane. A headframe is located near the Grass Valley Scrap, Iron & Metal yard. Learn more about the mine from Gold in Quartz: The Legendary Idaho Maryland Mine by Jack Clark, or from MacBoyle's Gold by Gage McKinney, both available from Comstock Bonanza Press.

properties.Name: Railroad and Transportation Museum
properties.Location: Five Kidder Court, Nevada City. Take Ridge Rd exit off Hwy 49
properties.Description: The Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad (1876_1942) ran 22 miles from Nevada City through Grass Valley, its headquarters; to Colfax, Placer County, where it met the transcontinental line of the Central (later Southern) Pacific Railroad. Built by John F. Kidder, it was the main freight and passenger route serving the western county. Kidder ran the railroad until his death in 1901 and was followed by his widow Sarah, who became the first woman railroad president in United States. She served until 1913. This museum is dedicated to preserving the NCNGRR's place in history and to those who built, operated and maintained the little road. Second plaque dedicated 2011 by Native Sons of the Golden West: Railroad and Transportation Museum. The Nevada County Historical Society founded the Transportation Museum Division in 1983 to acquire, document, restore and preserve information and artifacts pertaining to Nevada County's railroad and transportation history. Best known is the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad that operated from 1876 until 1942. The museum opened for public enjoyment on March 17, 2003.

properties.Name: Nevada County Narrow Gauge RR (II)
properties.Location: Railroad Avenue at Sacramento St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad was dedicated May 20, 1876 one hundred feet east of this spot. Built by John Flint Kidder between 1874-76 it ran 22 miles from Nevada City to Colfax via Grass Valley. Rails taken up in 1942. Sarah Kidder, widow of builder, worldÍs first woman railroad president 1901-13.

properties.Name: Nevada City Jewish Cemetery
properties.Location: End of King Hiram Lane, off Searls Ave, Nevada City
properties.Description: The Nevada City Jewish Cemetery was established in 1854. The first burial was in 1856 and the last in 1890. Twenty nine headstones are visible, including that of Louis W. Dreyfuss, a cousin of Captain Alfred Dreyfus of France, the victim in the infamous Dreyfus Affair. The cemetery was restored around 50 years ago by the Commission for the Preservation of Pioneer Jewish Cemeteries and Landmarks. It is locked and fenced to protect against vandalism. Note: For more information see A Traveler's Guide to Pioneer Jewish Cemeteries of the California Gold Rush by Susan Morris.

properties.Name: Hydraulic Mining
properties.Location: Railroad Ave at back entrance to Northern Queen Inn, Nevada City
properties.Description: The first hydraulic mining originated here at American Hill Diggins by Edward Matteson in 1853. Matteson originally used canvas hose. The canvas hose was replaced with crinoline hose in 1860. These miners' giants, also known as water cannons, monitors and dictators, washed hillsides away with high pressure water, uncovering gold bearing beds. This mining technique flourished profitably until 1884. Rivers were being filled with mud and debris causing flooding of the rich farm lands in the valley. At that time, a lawsuit brought by farmers against hydraulic mining was heard in Marysville, California where a decision known as The Sawyer Decision stopped all mining. Under a special use permit, granted by the Department of Fish and Game, these hydraulic monitors were last used at the Pacific Slab Mine near Foresthill, California in 1970, which was documented by the California Department of Parks and Recreation.

properties.Name: Pioneer Cemetery
properties.Location: East side of W. Broad St, near Hwy 49, Nevada City
properties.Description: This cemetery was established in 1851 on a knoll back of the First Methodist Church. This gave the site its name. Many noted citizens rest here. Note: The first cemetery in Nevada County after arrival of the 49ers. Located in the churchyard of the first Methodist Church that once occupied this site, it has been in use since 1851. A wooden marker was placed in 1949. The plaque is on a stone monument in the front part of the cemetery. Many famous pioneers and early settlers are buried here, including Henry Meredith and William Alphonso Sutter, the son of General John Sutter. Aaron A. Sargent's cenotaph is here though his remains were cremated and scattered by air above the Quaker Hill Mine, which he used to own.

properties.Name: Englebright House
properties.Location: 524 E. Broad St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Notable as one of the earliest recorded houses in Nevada City and for its history of prominent owners. The tradition that the legendary William Morris Stewart built the house in 1853 cannot be documented for no deeds remain earlier than 1858. However, the house appears as the residence of P. G. Womack in the first map of the city prepared in 1855 and published in 1856. Other owners included the famous mining engineer, Capt. Thos. Mein, whose son William Wallace Mein was born in the house in 1873. The family of the late U.S. Representative Harry Englebright purchased the house in 1897 and resided there until 1959. The interior shows the work of many occupants and the exterior reflects eclectic borrowings from many past styles.

properties.Name: Nathaniel P. Brown House
properties.Location: 528 E Broad St Nevada City
properties.Description: Nathaniel P. Brown, founding owner of the Nevada Daily Transcript and early political figure in Nevada City, lived here from 1865 until 1909. He expanded the original cottage to its current size in the 1880s, allowing for frequent entertaining. The home was built in 1858 by Jesse S. Wall, an early settler and merchant. Nathaniel Brown came to Nevada City from Massachusetts in 1853 at the age of 18, following his friend Aaron Sargent. He was part owner of the weekly Nevada Journal from 1855 to 1859. In 1860, Brown founded the countyÍs first daily, the Morning Transcript, and from then until 1904 was prominent in newspaper circles and a constant champion of mine ownerÍs rights. The most famous resident of the house was opera diva Emma Nevada. While her father, Dr. W. W. Wixom, sought a new home for his family, Emma and her mother boarded here until 1864. Between the ages of 4 and 13 she resided at Austin, Nevada. Emma Wixom achieved great fame as a singer and took the stage name Nevada to honor the state in which she grew up and the county where she was born. She returned to Nevada City in 1902 and performed to a packed audience at the Nevada Theatre.

properties.Name: Indian Medicine Stone
properties.Location: 621 E. Broad St, opposite N. Pine St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Pioneer Emigrant Trail. This boulder was known to the pioneers as the Indian Medicine Stone. On its top are hollows in which the Indians lay while taking sun baths to cure their ills. One branch of the Emigrant Trail leading from Truckee Pass to the gold mines of Nevada County and to the Valley of the Sacramento passed close beside this stone.

properties.Name: 545 Main Street
properties.Location: 545 Main St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Druggist and County Treasurer Edward F. Spence built this house on 3 lots in 1866 and lived here with his wife Marietta until her death in 1868. He founded Spenceville, organized banks in San Jose and Southern California, served as Mayor of Los Angeles, and was instrumental in establishing the Mt. Wilson Observatory. County Judge Addison C. Niles bought the house from Spence in 1870 and occupied it with his wife Elizabeth until his election to the California Supreme Court in 1871. The City of Niles, California, is named for him. Niles Searls bought the house from his brother-in-law, Addison Niles, in 1871. When he became a Supreme Court Commissioner in 1885 he and his wife Mary gave the house to son Fred and his bride, Helen Pond, as a wedding present. In 1887 Niles Searls became Chief Justice of the California Supreme Court, and served on the Supreme Court Commission from 1893 to 1899. Attorney Fred Searls (a native of Nevada City) and his wife Helen (a native of Downieville) lived here from 1885 until his death in 1929. The last member of the family to reside here was Fred Searls III, great-grandson of Niles Searls.

properties.Name: Baruh House
properties.Location: 516 Main St Nevada City
properties.Description: The Baruh Home Built 1852. This site and home of two rooms was bought in 1866 by Mr. and Mrs. A. Baruh, grandparents of Mrs. Lucille Sherwood. Mrs. Clara Baruh Quigley, a charter member of Laurel Parlor No. 6, Native Daughters of the Golden West. Mr. Joseph Baruh, son, charter member of Hydraulic Parlor No. 56, Native Sons of the Golden West. Other family members: daughters Jenny Baruh Zellerbach, Rebecca Baruh Gabriel, sons Moses, Marcus and David. Mr. Aaron Baruh was a businessman operating a grocery store on Commercial Street, receiving gold dust for the commodities in the gold rush area. Later he operated a saloon and was very active in the early settlement of Nevada City. Note: Originally built by Jacob Coleman as a two-room cottage, it was expanded in 1866 by Aaron Baruh.

properties.Name: Saint Canice Catholic Church
properties.Location: Corner Washington and Coyote Sts, Nevada City
properties.Description: Historic St. Canice Catholic Church was built and first services held in 1864 under the guidance of Father John Griffin. Note: This also is site of St. Peter and St. Paul Catholic Church, built in 1857 and destroyed by fire in 1863.

properties.Name: Old Brick Gothic Church Building
properties.Location: Corner of Main and Church Sts, Nevada City
properties.Description: Historic Old Brick Gothic Building. Constructed as a Congregational Church in 1857. Restored by First Baptist Church. Notes: Also site of Nevada City’s pioneer nondenominational church, which burned in March 1851. It was replaced by a wooden Congregational Church, that burned in 1856. Cornerstone of this brick building was laid on July 4, 1858 (not 1857.) The roof and interior burned in 1863 and the church was rebuilt once more in 1864. The University of California was born at the church in 1853, when Henry Durant took part in a convention of Congregationalists and Presbyterians who resolved to establish a college in California. Durant soon opened the Contra Costa Academy in Oakland, that become the College of California then relocated to Berkeley as the University of California.

properties.Name: Nevada County Court House
properties.Location: 201 Church St, on left side of entrance, Nevada City
properties.Description: Nevada County Courthouse History. Nevada County organized out of Yuba County May 11,1851. Wooden court-house and log jail built on Broad Street in 1851. The first courthouse on this site was erected in 1856. The building was damaged by fire in July of the same year and rebuilt. Destroyed by fire in 1863 and rebuilt in 1864. Remodeled and enlarged in 1900. Modernized and enlarged 1936-37, George C. Sellon, Architect, Lindgren and Swinerton, Inc., Contractors, Robert Steger, Building Superintendent.

properties.Name: First Brick Building in Nevada City
properties.Location: 212 Church St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Built in 1853. First brick building erected in this city. Dedicated to the memory of the pioneers of Nevada City. Note: This originally was the Dickerman carpenter shop. Bricks for this building were manufactured at Zeno P. Davis's brickyard on Lower Grass Valley Rd. in Nevada City (now called Searls Ave).

properties.Name: Searls Law Office
properties.Location: 214 Church St,  Nevada City
properties.Description: This building completed December 18, 1872, was the law office for three generations of this family. Niles Searls, who arrived in 1851, practiced law here from 1872 to 1885. He had been elected district attorney in 1855, then district judge for Nevada, Sierra and Yuba counties, then became Chief Justice of the California Supreme Court in 1887. Fred Searls, his son, held the longest tenure in this building (1879-1929). He drafted the first incorporation papers of the hydroelectric industry of California. Carroll Searls, son of Fred, practiced here from 1915 to 1923; later became general counsel of the Newmont Mining Company in New York City; used this office until November 4,1970. Note: Niles Searls was elected district attorney in 1852, not 1855, but because he left California and went east to marry before his term of office began, William M. Stewart was appointed to fill the vacancy. Later, when Stewart resigned in 1854 to become the acting state attorney general, Searls was appointed to replace him as district attorney. From 1972 until 2014 the building housed the Historical SocietyÍs Searls Historical Library and Archives.

properties.Name: Doris Foley Library of Historical Research
properties.Location: 211 N. Pine St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Nevada City Public Library. Library Association formed December 19, 1857. First library was in Kidd and Knox Building, 228 Broad Street. It was moved to Oustamah Lodge IOOF No. 16 June 3, 1874. Nevada City Trustees assumed responsibilities October 1, 1902 and was moved into the Corcoran Building next to the Nevada Theater. The Carnegie Endowment was given to the city in 1907. The present library was dedicated October 4, 1907. City groups raised funds for furnishings and beautified grounds 1911. Note: In 1996 the Nevada City Council, the Nevada County Board of Supervisors, and the Nevada County Historical Landmarks Commission voted to rename this library for Doris Foley, an outstanding historian and author who contributed greatly to scholarly research in this county. In addition to her writings, she helped found the Nevada County Historical Society and was the first librarian at Searls Historical Library. The Doris Foley Library of Historical Research was formally dedicated on May 17,1997.

properties.Name: Nevada City Firehouse No. 1
properties.Location: 214 Main St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Nevada Hose Co. No. 1 Occupied this firehouse from May 30, 1861 to 1938. Hand pulled hose carts, horse drawn engines and motorized pumpers all rolled out of this building to save life and property. Note: The building now houses the Historical Society Museum.

properties.Name: South Yuba Canal Office
properties.Location: Robinson Plaza
properties.Description: Headquarters for the largest network of water flumes and ditches In the state. The South Yuba Canal Water Company was the first incorporated to supply water for hydraulic mining. The original ditch was in use in May, 1850, and this company office was in use from 1857 to 1880. The holdings later became the vast P.G. & E. hydro-electric system.Second plaque dedicated 1987 by Native Sons of the Golden West: US Constitution 1787 Bicentennial 1987 Nevada City, a Bicentennial Community. The plaques are mounted on adjacent brick buildings. The one on the left originally was the Potter Building and the other began life as the City Drugstore, Both survived the great fire of 1856 and are two of the oldest in Nevada City. The South Yuba Canal Water Company did not occupy the building until 1861.

properties.Name: Five-Stamp Mill 1893
properties.Location: Robinson Plaza
properties.Description: Used to crush gold ore at the Fortuna Mine near Nevada City. Ore fed under iron 'stamps' from rear hopper. Steam, water or electric belt-driven power turned wheel which revolved cams. Donated to Nevada City by Bill Magers.

properties.Name: Pelton Water Wheel
properties.Location: Robinson Plaza
properties.Description: No. 4, 1928-1987. Produced 18,000 HP at 257 RPM and enough electrical power for 16,000 households. 12 ft. diameter, weight 15 tons. Built in San Francisco by Pelton Company. A Constitutional Bicentennial gift to Nevada City by Pacific Gas and Electric.

properties.Name: Original Ott Assay Office Site
properties.Location: Robinson Plaza
properties.Description: Site of the Original Ott Assay Office. J. J. Ott's assay in 1859 helped develop the great Comstock Lode and the State of Nevada. Note: Ott’s original Assay Office was built of wood. It burned in the fire of 1863 and Ott moved into the existing brick building next door.

properties.Name: Wells Fargo Building Site Nevada City
properties.Location: Robinson Plaza
properties.Description: Site of Old Wells Fargo Building 1853. Dedicated to the Pioneers of California by Hydraulic Parlor No. 56 N.S.G.W. July 5, 1926. Plaque erected by Wells Fargo Bank and Union Trust Co. S.F. Calif.

properties.Name: Calanan Park Monitor
properties.Location: Calanan Park
properties.Description: The first hydraulic mining originated on American Hill near Nevada City, California in 1853. This miner’s giant known as the monitor washed hillsides away under high pressure uncovering gold bearing gravel beds. This mining technique flourished profitably until 1884 when the Sawyer decision closed hydraulic mining. Rivers were being filled with mud and debris causing flooding of the rich farmlands below.
