properties.Name: Calanan Park Drill Core
properties.Location: Calanan Park
properties.Description: Shaft Drill Core 1935-1936. Experimental vertical shaft, 5' in diameter to 1125' depth thru serpentine and gabbro at Idaho-Maryland Gold Mine, Grass Valley. Machinery invented by J. B. Newsom. Greatest drilled footage, 21' in three days. Core weight 11-tons. Donated to Nevada City by Kenneth E. Baker.

properties.Name: Nevada City Downtown Historic DIstrict
properties.Location: Calanan Park
properties.Description: Nevada City, the 'Queen City of the Northern Mines', became a town of 10,000 to 16,000 in the early 1850s following the discovery of gold on Deer Creek in 1849. Here is located the largest and best preserved historical downtown district in California Gold Country. As the county seat of Nevada County, Nevada City has maintained its position as the countyÍs center of government, professional services and cultural activities since its beginning in 1851 Entered National Register of Historic Places September 23,1985. Note: This includes only the downtown district, as contrasted to the Nevada City Historic District defined by the city in 1968.

properties.Name: Kidd and Knox Building
properties.Location: Northeast corner Pine and Broad Sts, Nevada City
properties.Description: Kidd & Knox Building 1856. Major commercial building since gold rush. early offices of judges, lawyers, statesmen including U.S. Senators A. A. Sargent, Wm. Morris Stewart; Calif. Supreme Court Chief Justices Niles Searls, Lorenzo Sawyer were here.

properties.Name: Nevada County Traction Company
properties.Location: Corner of Pine and Broad Sts, Nevada City
properties.Description: Nevada County Traction Company 1901-1924. Our 28-ton standard gauge street cars ran from this spot five miles to Boston Ravine south of Grass Valley. Car barns and power plant located at Glenbrook mid-way. Line was victim of motor cars and busses.

properties.Name: Nevada City Firehouse No. 2
properties.Location: 420 Broad St. Nevada City
properties.Description: Firehouse #2 or Pennsylvania Engine Company #2 January 14,1861. Fire company formed June 13,1860 as Eureka Hose No. 2 with 34 volunteers. Name changed in August of that year to 'Pennsylvania Engine.' Construction money raised in 1859 by popular subscription and a grand ball staged by the townÍs women. This firehouse has been in continuous use since 1861. Note: The name change occurred after Eureka Hose #2 bought a used hose wagon from Pennsylvania Hose Co #12 in San Francisco. Because it was the easiest thing to do, they scratched off the 1 in #12  with a pen knife and changed their name to Pennsylvania Engine Company #2. The wagon is on display at the Wagon Shed (No. 113) in Pioneer Park.

properties.Name: Ten Stamp Mill
properties.Location: City parking lot on Commercial St, west of York St, Nevada City
properties.Description: 'Six tall, upright rods of iron, as large as a manÍs ankle, and heavily shod with a mass of iron and steel at their lower ends . . .' So begins Mark Twain’s description of a Nevada stamp mill.' ... These rose and fell, one after the other, in a ponderous dance, in an iron box called a battery.' Each of the stamps weighed 600 pounds. 'One of us stood by the battery all day long, breaking up masses of silver-bearing rock with a sledge and shoveling it in.'  At the end of his brief stint shoveling ore into the Nevada stamp mill, Twain told his boss he thought the $10 a week was not quite enough. He asked for a new wage of $400,000 a month. He didn't get it and had to become a newspaperman.This ten stamp mill stands just two blocks from where it was manufactured at Miners Foundry in 1904. It operated at the Alpha mine in Sierra County from 1905 until 1931. Each stamp weighs 1,000 pounds and was used to crush gold-bearing rock. Gary Cope recovered the stamp mill in 1975. It was bought and erected on this site, Native Sons Park, by Hydraulic Parlor No. 56 of the Native Sons of the Golden West with the help of the Historic Preservation Foundation of the N.S.G.W. in 2005.

properties.Name: Aaron Augustus Sargent Homestead
properties.Location: 449 Broad St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Homesteads of Nevada County’s Statesman, a 49er. Arrived here In 1850 as a journeyman printer. Editor and owner of the countyÍs first newspaper the Nevada Journal. Admitted to the bar 1854. District Attorney 1855-1857. First citizen elected to the House of Representatives 37th Congress 1861-1863; 41st and 42nd Congresses 1869-1873. First citizen elected to the United States Senate 1873-1879. Yeoman of the Republican Party. Author of the bill which created the first transcontinental railroad. Champion of the womanÍs suffrage movement, author of the Anthony Amendment giving women the right to vote; author of the Immigration Law, the first United States policy on immigration; author of the bill that revolutionized the mining industry, permitting mineral lands to be held in fee simple; author of the bill making the Pacific states and territories a U.S. Judicial Circuit; secured passage of the bill to establish a branch mint in the State of Nevada; secured appropriations for the construction of the mint and appraiser’s building in San Francisco. Envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary from the United States to the Court of Berlin, Germany, 1882-1884. Note: Ellen Clark Sargent, Aaron's wife, was one of the founders of the American suffrage movement. In 1869, she founded the Nevada County Women's Suffrage Organization. She was later president of the California Woman Suffrage association, and treasurer of the National Woman Suffrage Association. She was an associate of Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton. Sargent homes were always open to suffragists.

properties.Name: Nevada City Methodist Church
properties.Location: Corner Broad and Mill Sts, Nevada City
properties.Description: Historic Nevada City Methodist Church. Dedicated in 1864. Now one of the oldest existing churches.

properties.Name: Nevada Theatre
properties.Location: 401 Broad St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Opened Sept. 11, 1865 with comic Dan Setchell and dancers Worrell Sisters. Built by Geo. S. Pierce. Mark Twain, Emma Nevada, Jack London, Gilbert Barry and Richard Jose performed here. Movies shown from 1908-1958 Acquired 1967 by Liberal Arts Commission for restoration. Second plaque dedicated 1974 by State of California in cooperation with the Nevada County Historical Landmarks and Liberal Arts Commissions: CaliforniaÍs oldest existing theatre building, the Nevada, opened September 9, 1865. Celebrities such as Mark Twain, Jack London and Emma Nevada have appeared on its stage. Closed in 1957, the theatre was later purchased through public donations and reopened May 17, 1968 to again serve the cultural needs of the community. Note: Jack London’s appearance in the Nevada Theatre is undocumented and Gilbert Barry's may be a Clamper fabrication.

properties.Name: Nevada City Hall
properties.Location: 317 Broad St, Nevada City
properties.Description: First plaque dedicated 1937 by Native Sons of the Golden West: Dedicated June 19,1937 to the Pioneer Councilmen who erected the first City Hall  Felix Gillet, K. Casper, J. C. Locklin, Alec. Gault, Dan. Baker and to H. D. Shearer and Wm. H. Kilroy Officers who were killed in line of duty.... Second plaque (on floor of porch): This building dedicated to Truth-Liberty-Toleration by the Native Sons of the Golden West June 19,1937.Third plaque dedicated 1987 by Native Sons of the Golden West: U. S. Constitution. 1787 Bicentennial Nevada City. A Bicentennial Community. Fourth plaque dedicated 2000 by Nevada City Council: On February 14, 2000 a contract was executed, authorizing the completion of work that began in 1937. On that date, the City Council inaugurated a process by which a small, historically significant City Hall was transformed into a spacious and efficient public facility. Expansion and renovation have been fruitful to the original architectural style and designed to serve the community far in to the 21st century.... Dedicated to all who came before us and all who will follow. Fifth plaque dedicated 2000 by Nevada City Council: On the occasion of the dedication of a new City Hall at this location on December 19, 2000, the citizens and City Council of Nevada City humbly submit for posterity a time capsule secured in a concrete vault beneath this marker. Contained within are artifacts and documents representative of life in Nevada City as we prepare to embrace the uncharted future. We respectfully request this repository remain undisturbed until April 17, 2150, at which time Nevada City will celebrate its 300th birthday.

properties.Name: The Flagg Building
properties.Location: 223 Broad St, Nevada City
properties.Description: The Flagg Bldg. The Eternal Saloon. Built in 1856 on the site of the U.S. Hotel, this brick edifice has served Nevada City as the council chamber, Schreiber's, and since 1957 Eddie Furano's Bank Club. Here at Schreiber’s Felix, the marvelous, mysterious music box thundered Strauss waltzes and 'Carmen' to generations with custom and good cheer.

properties.Name: National Exchange Hotel
properties.Location: 211 Broad St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Originally the Bicknell Block, stagecoach, mail, express and telegraph center in mining days. Companies which became the Pacific Gas & Electric formed here. Site of first whipping post in state. Facade unchanged since 1854. This hotel, one of the oldest in continuous operation west of the Rockies, opened for business in August, 1856. Originally known as the 'Bicknell Block,' the structure consists of three common-walled buildings of simple brick construction embellished with classic revival and wrought iron railing ornamentation.

properties.Name: Ladies of the Evening
properties.Location: Under oak tree in National Hotel parking lot on Broad St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Plaque dedicated 1972 by Chap 10 E Clampus Vitus: To commemorate that ubiquitous segment of society who have been unacknowledged; who though obscure, made an essential contribution to the settlement of the West. Note: That segment of society made its contribution in the block of Spring Street that runs behind the hotel.

properties.Name: Powell House
properties.Location: Southeast corner Pine and Spring Sts, Nevada City
properties.Description: Built in 1855 as the edifice of the Baptist Church. It was here that famed soprano Emma Nevada (Emma Wixom Palmer) made her debut at the age of three. In 1886 the church was remodeled as the residence of the E. T. R. Powell family. Note: The building now houses apartments.

properties.Name: Miners Foundry
properties.Location: 325 Spring St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Miners' Foundry (AllanÍs Machine Shop) Founded 1856. This original brick building in continuous usage as a Foundry for over 100 years. Famous Pelton waterwheel developed and manufactured here in 1878. Ingenious double-cupped bucket design by Lester A. Pelton of Camptonville and Nevada City. It became the basis for hydro-electric turbine generators throughout the world. Second plaque dedicated 1994 by State of California: Pelton Wheel Manufacturing Site. The Pelton Water Wheel, first commercially manufactured at George AllanÍs Foundry & Machine Works in 1879 was a major advancement in water power and revolutionized hard rock mining technology. Its unique feature was a series of paired buckets, shaped like bowls or spoons and separated by a splitter, that divided the incoming water into two parts. By the late 1800s, the Pelton Wheels were providing energy to operate water powered machinery throughout the world. In 1888, Lester Pelton moved his business to San Francisco, but granted continuing manufacturing rights to AllanÍs Foundry, where the wheels were manufactured into the early 1900s, when most local mines shifted to electric power.  Note: Opened in 1855, the foundry was moved to its present location after the fire of 1856, and supplied equipment to the milling shops of many mines. Notable equipment included the Patent Mill Guide installed at the Tonopah Mine in Nevada and a gadget known as the Miners Foundry Ejector that had universal demand. Edward Matteson's hydraulic derrick, used to extract rocks from streams and rivers, was perfected here. Much of our modern electricity comes from generators driven by descendants of the Pelton Wheel. Occupied in the 1970s and 1980s by the American Victorian Museum, the building now houses the Miners Foundry Cultural Center.

properties.Name: William Morris Stewart House
properties.Location: 416 Zion St, Nevada City
properties.Description: William Morris Stewart Mansion Built 1855-56. Exact replica of wifeÍs ante-bellum colonial birthplace. Only edifice of this type in California. Stewart, an early Nevada County district attorney, joined the 1859 Comstock silver rush, led battle for statehood and became Nevada’s first U.S. Senator. Served 29 years known as the Silver Senator and Father of American mining law. Authored 15th Constitutional Amendment. Note: The Stewart family occupied the home for only a short time before selling the house in 1857 to Judge Niles Searls, whose family lived here from 1858 to 1862.

properties.Name: Trinity Episcopal Church
properties.Location: Corner of Nevada and High Sts, Nevada City
properties.Description: Trinity Episcopal Church. Founded as a parish in 1855, opened for Divine Service in this building on November 2, 1873. Previously on this site was ‘Caldwell's Upper Store' built in 1849 for the miners of Upper Deer Creek Dry Diggings, now known as Nevada City, and Washington School, 1863, the community’s first high school. The present building was erected by shipwrights working in the mines. Their craftsmanship may be seen in its construction. Notes: CaldwellÍs Upper Store and Deer Creek Dry Diggings were the original names for the mining community that became Nevada City. In 1856 W. H. Orr built a brick house here that was used as a public high school from 1862 to 1869. The house was removed in 1871, two years before Trinity Church was built.

properties.Name: Charles Marsh House
properties.Location: 123 Nevada St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Built about 1866 by Charles Marsh, who arrived here in July, 1849, in what would later become Nevada City. Marsh was the first County Surveyor and the first County Supervisor from Nevada City. He created the water distribution system which formed the basis for P.G.& E. and the Nevada Irrigation District. Marsh was influential in the routing of the Central Pacific Railroad and served on its original Board of Directors, as well as the Board of the Nevada County Narrow Gauge Railroad. He was also instrumental in creating a Library Association in Nevada City.

properties.Name: Colley House
properties.Location: 116 Nevada St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Queen Anne Style Built in 1860 Home of Ida Colley and niece, Winifred Mulloy, founders of Laurel Parlor #6 Native Daughters of the Golden West. Now Deer Creek Inn Bed & Breakfast.

properties.Name: Plaza Grocery
properties.Location: 101 Broad St, Nevada City
properties.Description: This store, opened in 1882 by Tom Shurtleff, contained the only water-powered elevator in Nevada County. Longest continuous operation of any Nevada City grocery until it closed in 1973. Note: Building was a boarding house from 1880 to 1882. Celio family bought it in 1910 and leased to Scheemers in 1928. John Sbaffi bought the business in 1949 and purchased the building in 1965. It was a grocery until 1973, when 'The Jacks' leased it for use as a restaurant. It has been used primarily as a bar or restaurant since.

properties.Name: Nevada Brewery
properties.Location: Corner Sacramento and Boulder Sts, Nevada City
properties.Description: The Old Brewery. Constructed of granite blocks from the Sierras about 1882. Where Simon C. Hieronimus & family brewed and served lager beer to Nevada City, Queen of the Northern Mines and hydraulic mining communities. Note: This brewery was erected on the site of Temperance Hall after that building burned. After his brewery on Searls Avenue (See 102) burned in 1893, Simon Hieronimus brewed his beer in this building until he died in 1911.

properties.Name: Allen Chapman House
properties.Location: 227 Sacramento St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Allen Chapman House Built in 1856. The home and dental office of Allen Chapman, Nellie Chapman, and their son C. W. Chapman. Nellie Pooler Chapman was the first woman licensed to practice dentistry in the western United States.

properties.Name: The Red Castle
properties.Location: 109 Prospect St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Nevada City’s earliest surviving brick home, built in 1860 by Judge John Williams, mine owner, businessman and civic leader, who with his family, crossed the plains in 1849. Near ruin, this house was restored by James Wade Schaar in 1963. The Red Castle stands today as a proud reminder of the part the Argonauts played in the Heritage of California.

properties.Name: Memorial Grove Nevada City
properties.Location: Max Solaro Dr, Pioneer Park, Nevada City
properties.Description: This grove honors those who served our country in the armed forces. It contains five plaques.Plaque dedicated 1946 by the citizens of Nevada City: This plot of land set aside by the City of Nevada, these trees living tributes to our war dead. This plaque and flag pole erected by the citizens of Nevada City dedicated July 4, 1946 to the memory of our heroes who gave their lives in World War II that the American way of life may continue. Caswell Fisher, Tevis Ferguson, Merton Downey, Donald Osrey, Bert Graham, Fred Doby, Eugene Davies, Albert Conti, Ernest Chapman, William G. Bennett, Hans G. Hirsef, Clifford M. Ruth, Timothy R. Livesay, Virgil Roseborough, David McCreary, Eugene Rickard, Robert D. Proctor, Louis G. Netz, Glenn Ponticelli , Walter O. St. John, Carl D. Tobiassen, Gus Wasley, James M. Odegaard, William Pohley, Reid Shurtleff.Plaque dedicated 1990 by Banner Mountain Post No. 2655, Veterans of Foreign Wars: Korea, June 25, 1950 - July 27, 1953, 'The Forgotten War - Remembered.' Let us not forget those Americans who served, those who died and those who still remain on that foreign soil in defense of freedom. As a result of that war: 54,246 Americans were killed 8,177 Americans are missing in action 389 Americans are prisoners of war.Plaque dedicated 1992 by Banner Mountain Post No. 2655, Veterans of Foreign Wars: Vietnam. All gave some - some gave all. If you are able, save for them a place inside of you and save one, backward glance when you are leaving for the places they can no longer, go. Be not ashamed to say you loved them, though you may or may not, have always. Take what they have left and what they have taught you, with their dying and keep it with your own. And in that time when men, decide and feel safe to call the war insane, take one moment to, embrace those gentle heroes you left behind. - Major Michael Davis O'Donnell, 1 January 1970, Dak To, Vietnam. Note: Major O'Donnell was a helicopter pilot. On 24 March 1970, while attempting to rescue eight soldiers, his chopper was shot down. He and, three crew members were declared missing in action. This memorial plaque is dedicated as a tribute to those who served and fought in the Vietnam War, especially those who died, and those yet to return. Plaque dedicated 1995 by Banner Mountain Post No. 2655, Veterans of Foreign Wars: POW MIA You are not forgotten.Plaque dedicated 2007 by the citizens of Nevada County: War on Terror  We Will not Forget.In honor of the Men and Women who have served and will serve in the ongoing Global War on Terror and to those Valiant Few who have given their lives, therein... . We, the citizens of Nevada County, dedicate this memorial. L/Cpl Adam Strain, 20, L/Cpl John 'J.T.' Lucente, 19, 1st Lt. Nathan Krisoff, 25, Cpl Sean Stokes, 24, Ssg David P. Senft, 27.There are also memorial plaques for the following Vietnam veterans located on the following Golden Center Freeway overpasses around Nevada City.PfcUSA: Philip A. Tritsch 06/10/1943-01/28/1969, west end Washington StSP/4 101st ABN: Ronald J. Walber 06/3/1948-04/25/1968, west end Broad St Michael D. Goeller 06/2/1948-06/01/1969, east end Sacramento StCapt USA: John Stuart Seeley 04/10/1932-06/27/1966, west end Gold Flat Rd1st Lt USA: James F

properties.Name: Isabel Hefelfinger Wagon Shed
properties.Location: Max Solaro Dr, Pioneer Park, Nevada City
properties.Description: The Wagon Shed. Generations of Californians living in the northern mines depended for their economics and social well-being on wheel transportation powered by the horse, mule, the ox. The vehicles displayed here represent some of those used to move people, goods and gold. The Nevada County Historical Society, Hydraulic Parlor No. 56, City of Nevada City, California Department of Parks & Recreation, Nevada City Lions Club and many other civic groups and individuals cooperated to preserve this collection.Second plaque dedicated 1993 by the Historical Society: Isabel Hefelfinger Wagon Shed. This building is dedicated to the memory of Isabel Ross Hefelfinger (1899-1991). She encouraged many by her interest and dedication in remembering the past. Her untiring efforts to preserve history of Nevada County will not be forgotten.

properties.Name: Martin Luther Marsh House
properties.Location: 254 Boulder St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Martin Luther Marsh arrived in Nevada City in 1851 after a journey from Ohio by the Nicaragua route. He worked as a carpenter, left to mine at Iowa Hill and finally returned to enter the lumber business. With his brother Dan he set up a saw mill on Little Deer Creek (now Pioneer Park). The enterprise boomed and in 1873 Marsh built this magnificent home using carefully seasoned sugar pine for the interior woodwork. His granddaughter Lucille and her late husband James B. Christie restored the house in 1955.

properties.Name: American Hill Diggings
properties.Location: 150 W. Broad St, Nevada City
properties.Description: On this site in 1853 Edward E. Matteson developed one of the first hydraulic mines, an operation in which gold was washed from great quantities of earth with high pressure streams of water. The method used here became a standard of the mining industry through out the world.Second plaque dedicated 2006 by Native Sons of the Golden West: The Hydraulic Monitor, Pipe & Gate Valve displayed here was installed by Native Sons of the Golden West, Hydraulic Parlor 56, Nevada City, January 2006. Note: The first approach to hydraulic mining may have been that of Antoine Chabot, said to have used water to direct gravel into the sluicebox at Buckeye Hill in 1852. But Matteson fully developed the system in 1853 by attaching a nozzle to a rawhide hose to wash down soil for gold recovery at American Hill. By the 1860s Nevada County miners universally credited Matteson with the invention of hydraulic mining and other labor-saving devices.

properties.Name: Boardman House
properties.Location: 523 E Broad St NC
properties.Description: Notable as one of the earliest recorded houses in Nevada City and for its history of prominent owners. The tradition that the legendary William Morris Stewart built the house in 1853 cannot be documented for no deeds remain earlier than 1858. However, the house appears as the residence of P. G. Womack in the first map of the city prepared in 1855 and published in 1856. Other owners included the famous mining engineer, Capt. Thos. Mein, whose son William Wallace Mein was born in the house in 1873. The family of the late U.S. Representative Harry Englebright purchased the house in 1897 and resided there until 1959. The interior shows the work of many occupants and the exterior reflects eclectic borrowings from many past styles.

properties.Name: Robinson Plaza
properties.Location: Foot of Main St, Nevada City. The plaza is dedicated to Beryl Robinson and contains several  sites and plaques.
properties.Description: Robinson Plaza named for Beryl  Robinson Jr.  Born in Nevada City September 13, 1935. City Councilman-City Manager. On July 1,1999, Beryl Robinson Jr. became the longest-serving City Manager in state history. A native of the town he has so ably served, Beryl was appointed City Manager on June 21, 1965. In addition to being Nevada City's chief administrative and financial official, he has diligently worked to preserve the community's 19th-century spirit and buildings, including the two historic structures here at Robinson Plaza. Beryl's continuing career in public service has already spanned the terms of seven presidents, six governors and three-dozen council members. A Mason, Rotarian and Elk, Beryl has brought a sense of commitment and purpose two his life matched by few and bettered by none.

properties.Name: Calanan Park
properties.Location: Corner Broad and Union Sts, Nevada City. This small park is dedicated to George Calanan and contains several historical objects and plaques.
properties.Description: Text of plaque: Native Daughters Garden in George Calanan Park. In 1922, Laurel Parlor No. 6, Native Daughters of the Golden West acquired two small lots to create a memorial park for the veterans and those who died in World War I. In the interest of 'a valuable public improvement,' Laurel Parlor sold the lot to the U.S. Forest Service for a district office in 1936. The advent of World War II redirected federal resources and the planned 6,000 square foot building was never constructed. The lot remained a community park. In 1967, the park was dedicated to honor George Humphrey Calanan (1872- 1951), a much-loved Town Trustee (City Councilman), health officer, assessor, volunteer fireman, and long time City Clerk. He was known as 'the man who got things done.' The park was granted to the City of Nevada City by the United States Department of the Interior on December 1, 1971.

properties.Name: Hydraulic Gate Valve
properties.Location: Calanan Park
properties.Description: Hydraulic gold mining 21-inch gate valve 1880 Used at the You Bet-Red Dog Diggin's east of Nevada City periodically 1880- 1935 to control water flow from Chalk Bluff reservoir to the mine. Hydraulic nozzle mounted opposite was operated at that mine by Thomas B. Brady. Manufactured by Joshua Handy Works, San Francisco. Wt. 1,500 lbs. approx.  A gift from the Brady Family.

properties.Name: Nevada City Masonic Lodge
properties.Location: 108 N. Pine St. Nevada City
properties.Description: The year was 1850 at a location not far from here. The first Masonic Lodge meeting was held under a Charter from state of Wisconsin. Lafayette Lodge #29  was born, the years following in 1851 & 1863 a major part of which was to be known as Nevada City was destroyed by fires. By this time California was a State and a new Lodge of California Charter was established as Nevada #13 F&AM in 1851. At this location the first masonry structure was built in 1852 as a store. The 1863 fire destroyed this building and again the Lodge at a different place. This site was purchased for $1,650 and rebuilt as a store with Lodge rooms up stairs. The Lodge moved in 1864. A dining room/office extension was built to the right in 1901. Over the past 136 years other Masonic units/orders have also been meeting here. Royal Arch, Nevada Chapter #6,  Council #62, K. T Commandery #6, Evangeline Eastern Star #9. In honor of 150 years continuous Nevada Lodge #13 F&AM  Masonic Actives.  Grand Master of California Alvin J. Weis placed this plaque in rededication of this Lodge April 22, 2000.  Note: The plaque is quoted verbatim; all errors are in the original.

properties.Name: 400 Broad Street
properties.Location: 400 Broad St, Nevada City
properties.Description: Text of plaque: It was at this location on the afternoon of June 5, 1880 that a fire erupted in John White's upholstery shop. More than fifty buildings - including the nearby New York Hotel and most of the Chinese Quarter - were destroyed within an hour, but from the ashes of that conflagration a new business district emerged and York Street was created to ensure better downtown fire protection.  Then, early in the 20th century, a doctor's office was established here. The longest-serving physician to occupy this corner was Bernard W. Hummelt, MD (1906 - 1998), who, between 1934 and his retirement in 1988, practiced internal medicine, orthopedics and general surgery. Over the course of his lengthy career he delivered over 1500 Nevada County babies. Dr. Hummelt was among the earliest physicians in the nation to administer penicillin and was instrumental in the founding of Sierra Nevada Memorial Hospital - where he served as its third Chief of Staff. Placed by the family of Bernard W. Hummelt, M.D. to honor the centennial of Dr. Hummelt's birth August 5,1906 A remarkable life- an exemplary career.

properties.Name: Lindeboom Memorial
properties.Location: 415 N Pine St Nevada City
properties.Description: Plaque dedicated 1986 by Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 2655: Dedicated to the memory of Tina Lindeboom March 1911-February 1984. With gratitude and appreciation of the American people for gallant service in assisting Allied soldiers escape from the enemy W.W. II 1939-1945.

properties.Name: English and New Salmon Mine Stamp Mill
properties.Location: Miners Foundry, 325 Spring St, Nevada City
properties.Description: This stamp mill was manufactured at the Miners Foundry and Supply Co., Nevada City, California, in the late 1800’s. After a circuitous journey, it has returned to its place of origin. It started its industrial life of crushing hard rock at the English Mine, and then the New Salmon Mine, owned by Donald McPherson, at Badger Hill. The stamp mill ceased operation in 1942 when all non-critical gold mines were shut down. After sitting idle through the years overgrown by trees and brush the stamp mill was moved in the 1970’s to the Nevada City home of King McPherson, who generously donated the stamp mill back to the Miners Foundry in the 1980’s. The stamp mill sat in pieces around the foundry, despite several attempts to reconstruct it. Through the efforts of the members of Hydraulic Parlor No. 56, Native Sons of the Golden West under the supervision of Mike Nevius, restoration was completed in the spring of 2000.

properties.Name: Pine Street Crossing at Nevada City
properties.Location: S. Pine St at Deer Creek, Nevada City
properties.Description: Pine Street Bridge 1996. Third span of Deer Creek at this location. It is a replica of the single arch steel Gault bridge (1903-1996) which replaced the suspension bridge (1862-1903) built by Andrew S. Hallidie, who later built the San Francisco cable car system. Note: The bridge is officially named the South Pine Street Bridge at Hallidie Crossing. Hallidie's patented structure collapsed two weeks after it opened, killing two men. The Gault bridge, similar to the one at Edwards Crossing (No. 128) was named for Nevada City Mayor Alexander Gault.

properties.Name: Weiss-Hieronimus Brewery Cellar
properties.Location: 422 Searls Ave, Nevada City
properties.Description: The Weiss-Hieronimus Brewery Cellar. Beginning in the early 1860s and continuing until Prohibition, the lower portion of this building was the storeroom for keg beer produced first by Emille (sic) Weiss for the Weiss Brewery then by Simon Hieronimus for the Hieronimus Brewery_later known as the Nevada Brewery. As the brewery business grew, Mr. Hieronimus established a bottling plant and stable on property across the street from this building. But keg beer continued to be stored here. A fire in the summer of 1896 destroyed the original house and severely damaged the cellar. But the Nevada Brewery emerged bigger and better than ever. It was at that time that the cellar was enlarged to its present size, a ventilation system installed and refrigeration added. In 2004 the property was acquired by Jesse and Kay Connor, who carefully restored the old brewery cellar and home. This plaque has been placed to honor the legacy of both the Weiss and Hieronimus families and to remind people that the best lager beer in Nevada County was once produced here. Note: Messrs Weiss and Hieronimus were each born in France. Weiss arrived in Nevada City in 1850 and immediately opened a brewery. Hieronimus arrived in Nevada City in 1876, then operated a brewery in North Bloomfield before taking over this brewery.

properties.Name: Hunt's Hill (Gouge Eye)
properties.Location: About 6 m. east of Nevada City, off Buckeye Rd, about 1 m. from the intersection with Red Dog Rd
properties.Description: Hunt's Hill (also Gouge Eye) is a former mining camp founded in 1852 by a miner named Hunt. It was located on one of the deepest parts of the rich Blue Lead channel of gold-bearing gravel. In 1855, one of the mining claims established by some French miners, was “jumped.” During the fight, one of the French miners lost an eye. Thereafter, that mine, and sometimes the town, were called Gouge Eye. By 1857, the town boasted two saloons, a hotel, a blacksmith and stable, a butcher shop, a boot and shoe store, and several grocery stores. In 1858, a stage line from Nevada City arrived. By 1880, the town was reduced to a combined store and saloon and a few houses. Today, there are some private homes in the area but the old mining camp is just a historic site.

properties.Name: Sheriff David Fulton Douglass
properties.Location: Just past 15934 Airport Rd, 3/4 m. from junction with Lake Vera Rd, Nevada City
properties.Description: On this spot Sheriff Douglass, a Native Son of the Golden West, gave his life July 26, 1896, bravely performing his duty. Alone he tracked a highwayman to this retreat and both fell In battle. It is believed Douglass was pitted against two and that one escaped. The bodies lay parallel. Nearby is a second plaque identifying the spot where the bandit lay.

properties.Name: Purdon Crossing Bridge
properties.Location: Bottom of Purdon Rd at South Fork of Yuba River, north of Nevada City
properties.Description: Purdon Bridge 1895. Built by Cotton Brothers of Oakland, this steel bridge replaced several wooden bridges washed away in floods. It is the only bridge of the half-through truss design remaining in California. Purdon Crossing was a vital link of the main road from Nevada City to Downieville and the Northern Mines. Note: The unique quality of a half-through truss is that the deck is carried halfway between the top and bottom of the support structure; very few were built in California. First bridge at this site was built by William E. Robinson in 1854. In 1859 John Webber dismantled Robinson's Bridge and replaced it. Webber's Bridge washed away in December 1861 and was replaced by a rope suspension foot bridge in February 1862. Jesse Wall bought the foot bridge and crossing in the spring of 1862 and built a new bridge that summer. Wall sold it to James M. Black in 1864. Peter Purdon bought the bridge in 1870 and sold it to the county in 1890, which replaced it with this one in 1895.

properties.Name: North San Juan Fire Department
properties.Location: 10057 Reservoir St, North San Juan, off Hwy 49
properties.Description: First Fire Department. To the memory of the first fire department, organized 1862, George Murphy, first fire chief. Note: The building is now a community hall.

properties.Name: North San Juan
properties.Location: In North San Juan on front of Bigley's Market, Hwy 49
properties.Description: North San Juan 1853. Dedicated to the memory of the founder Christian Keinz and to all the pioneer argonauts of San Juan Ridge, who by their labor and fortitude contributed so greatly to the wealth and economy of Nevada County, California and the nation.

properties.Name: Wells Fargo Building, North San Juan
properties.Location: Corner of Flume St and Hwy 49, North San Juan
properties.Description: Wells Fargo & Company 1854. Office and holding center for gold and currency, 1854-60. Block & Furth Co. Clothing Store, 1861-69. Chinese Laundry and store operated by Happy Go Lucky, 1890-1920. Bar and liquor store since 1934. First saloon owner, ‘Ma' Cunningham, 1934.

properties.Name: Old North San Juan School
properties.Location: 29190 Hwy 49, south end of North San Juan
properties.Description: The first school building on this site was moved from Flume Street in 1869. It burned in 1924, and this building was moved here from Lake Vera. This site operated as a school from 1869 until 1984. It is currently used as a community center and library.

properties.Name: North San Juan Methodist Episcopal Church
properties.Location: End of Flume St off Hwy 49, North San Juan
properties.Description: Erected in 1857 at a cost of $1500, the structure Is the earliest existing church in the county. It contains early furnishings. Second plaque dedicated 1980 by the church board and Chap 10 E Clampus Vitus: North San Juan United Methodist Church 1856. One of the oldest of its faith in continuous operation in California. Escaped three major fires which destroyed the town. The Rev. H. B. Sheldon, first assigned pastor, rode circuit from Brandy City to French Corral on horseback.

properties.Name: Blue Tent
properties.Location: About 5 miles northeast of Nevada City, approximately at the intersection of N. Bloomfield and Blue Tent School Rds
properties.Description: Blue Tent is a historic mining community established in 1850 and named after its first dwelling, a tent made of blue denim. In its heyday, it had a population of over 350, and its own store, dancehall, blacksmith shop, boarding house and other buildings.  A non-denominational Union Church was erected in 1861, and a school was established in 1868. A substantial Chinatown existed just north of  Blue Tent. The community was connected by stage to Nevada City, and by the world's first long distance telephone line established in 1878, to the mining communities around the San Juan Ridge. A post office existed between 1878 and 1889. In addition to mining, Blue Tent for many years had a thriving industry harvesting ice and shipping it throughout California. Like many communities that depended on hydraulic mining, Blue Tent began to decline following the 1884 Sawyer decision, forbidding the discharge of mining debris into the Yuba River. As mining declined, agriculture began to predominate. Today, the Blue Tent district is a pleasant, rural, largely residential area. Not much evidence remains of the mining district, except the Blue Tent school, which is still at the site to which it was moved in 1892. It has been converted to a private residence, but remains painted a vivid blue.

properties.Name: Pioneer Emigrant Trail (II)
properties.Location: 10867 Coyote St, near North Bloomfield Rd, Nevada City
properties.Description: A branch of the Pioneer Emigrant Trail leading from Truckee Pass to the gold mines of Nevada County traversed Harmony Ridge down through this gap and on to the Valley of the Sacramento.

properties.Name: Pioneer Emigrant Trail (I)
properties.Location: On Airport Rd about 100 feet from junction with Lake Vera Rd, Nevada City
properties.Description: A branch of the Pioneer Emigrant Trail leading from Truckee Pass to the gold mines of Nevada County and to the Valley of the Sacramento divided on Harmony Ridge near the site of Lone Grave. One route circled the north horizon to Blue Tent, down to Selby Flat, up through this gap and on south.

properties.Name: Cherokee
properties.Location: North of Nevada City on Tyler Foote Rd, about 5 miles east of Hwy 49, just past Sages Rd
properties.Description: Cherokee is a former gold mining community In Nevada County, located on the San Juan Ridge about 4 miles east of North San Juan. At the time of the Gold Rush, this area was occupied by the Nisenan. The Gold Rush came to Cherokee in 1850, when a group of Cherokee Indians began mining there and gave it its name. The town's heyday was between 1856 and 1865. It had two hotels, the Grizzly and Curnow’s, saloons, several stores, a butcher, a shoe shop, a resident physician and drugstore, and a blacksmith. Its sawmill had a capacity of 10,000 ft. of lumber a day. The local newspaper was the Cherokee Journal. There was stagecoach service to Nevada City. After 1878, Cherokee was connected to the world’s first long distance telephone line which connected the mining communities along the San Juan Ridge from French Corral to the Bowman Lake area. The town began to decline in the 1880’s, after hydraulic mining was restricted by the Sawyer decision. By 1924, the town was reduced to "one store; and the people live principally by farming, very little active mining being carried on here." Today, all that remains of Cherokee is the schoolhouse located on Sages Road just north of Tyler Foote Crossing Road, the historic cemetery, and a lot of land scarred by hydraulic mining.

properties.Name: Edwards Crossing Bridge
properties.Location: On North Bloomfield Rd at South Fork of Yuba River, northeast of Nevada City
properties.Description: Built in 1904 by the American Bridge Company of steel-connection-pin design to replace a wooden structure built in 1862 by William Edwards. In 1854 Edwards began operations here with a ferry, and in 1855 he built a bridge and toll road between Blue Tent and Lake City. His first bridge washed away in December 1861, and was replaced in the following year. The county acquired the bridge sometime after 1880. Note: Both this and the similar Gault bridge at Nevada City (No. 99) were built under the supervision of Nevada County Surveyor W. W. Waggoner.

properties.Name: Columbia Hill School
properties.Location: Tyler Foote Rd, San Juan Ridge, 8.7 m. east of Hwy 49, northeast of Nevada City
properties.Description: The schoolhouse, built in 1875, was still in use as a school in the 1970's. In 1980 the State of California condemned the schoolhouse as unsafe. It was remodeled and used for a while as a community center. Later a new community center was established next door, and the old school building was used for other purposes. It is now known as the North Columbia Schoolhouse Cultural Center. The original Columbia Hill School was built prior to March 11,1867.

properties.Name: Foote's Crossing Road
properties.Location: From intersection of Cruzon Grade and Tyler-Foote Rds in Nevada County to Alleghany in Sierra County (See Note on access below)
properties.Description: Foote’s Crossing Road was built by A. D. Foote in 1913 as an all-season short-cut from Columbia Hill to the mines of the Alleghany area. Foote was president of the Tightner Mine Co., the largest gold producer in the region at that time. The road, a 15-foot shelf hanging on the sheer canyon wall above the Middle Fork of the Yuba River, is a spectacular engineering feat and scenic wonder. The rock walls, built without mortar are still intact today. Unforeseen difficulties in building the road caused it to far exceed specifications so Foote personally financed 60% of the total cost, the balance being paid by Nevada and Sierra counties and the U.S. Forest Service.

properties.Name: North Bloomfield Mining & Gravel  Co.
properties.Location: Malakoff Diggins State Park; 0.8 m. west of North Bloomfield on No. Bloomfield Rd
properties.Description: Landmark registered 1972 by State of California, CHL 852. Plaque dedicated 1972 by State in cooperation with Chap 10 E Clampus Vitus and Malakoff Citizens Advisory Committee: This was a major hydraulic operation in California. Its vast system of canals and flumes using a drainage tunnel 7800 feet long was termed a feat of engineering skill. It was the principal defendant in an anti-debris lawsuit settled by the Sawyer decision in 1884. SawyerÍs famous decision created controls that virtually ended hydraulic mining in California. Note on access: Park at Diggins Loop Trail Access and follow arrow to Scenic Overlook. To see plaque, take trail about 25 feet east of "No Dogs On Trail" sign. Plaque is about 300 feet from road. Note on Access: Over the 3 m. on either side of the Yuba, this road is narrow, steep, twisting and potentially hazardous. A high-clearance, four wheel drive vehicle is recommended.

properties.Name: Saint Columncille's Catholic Church
properties.Location: No. Bloomfield Rd, west of North Bloomfield, Malakoff Diggins State Park
properties.Description: The original plaque disappeared and was replaced in 1949 by Native Daughters of the Golden West by a wooden plaque: St. Columncille’s Catholic Church. Formerly the Bridgeport Union Guard Hall, was used in 1860 to train men for the Civil War under Capt. Frank Coffey of French Corral. In 1880, it was purchased as a house of worship for the Catholics of the ridge towns. Note: This building formerly was located at Birchville. In 1969 it was purchased by Babe Pinaglia and given to Malakoff Diggins Park, where it occupies the site of the Catholic Church that once served the miners of North Bloomfield.

properties.Name: North Bloomfield School
properties.Location: North side No. Bloomfield Rd, west end of North Bloomfield
properties.Description: North Bloomfield School 1872-73. Built at a cost of some 3,000 dollars. Modeled after schoolhouses at nearby Sebastopol and Sweetland, it served the community until closed in 1941. Acquired from Washington School District, Nevada County, for public use and display. Restoration commenced in 1973 by popular subscription.

properties.Name: Malakoff Diggins Clampicnic Area
properties.Location: Malakoff Diggins State Park, No. Bloomfield Rd just west of the old Grand Central Hote
properties.Description: This picnic area, sponsored by the Wm. Bull Meek-Wm. Morris Stewart Chapter No. 10 E Clampus Vitus, is for the enjoyment of all. The redwood lumber for the tables came from Nevada City’s Christmas Tree, a Sequoiadendron Giganteum, and continues to serve the residents and visitors of Nevada County.

properties.Name: Malakoff Diggins --North Bloomfield Historic District
properties.Location: Malakoff Diggins State Historic Park, No. Bloomfield Rd, 11 m. from Nevada City
properties.Description: Site of the worldÍs largest hydraulic gold mining operation. The North Bloomfield Mining Company purchased approximately 1500 acres near the settlement of Malakoff in 1866. Hydraulic mining exposed the area to enormous amounts of high pressure water through nozzles called 'monitors.' The application of pressurized water on the mountainsides of Malakoff left a 1600 acre pit 7000 feet long by 3000 feet wide. The awesome effects of the world’s largest hydraulic gold mining operation are still visible today. Note: According to historian Robert Wyckoff the La Grange Mine near Weaverville was larger.

properties.Name: Shoot (Chute) Hill
properties.Location: Across from space 29 in Chute Hill campground about 7/10 m. east of North Bloomfield
properties.Description: Local historians relate that water from high mountain lakes flowed thru a 500' wooden 'chute' which led to a huge square tank or pressure box behind campsite 29. Here it entered a 3' pipe reduced to gain pressure to 2', then down hill 200' to the hydraulic monitors at the mine.

properties.Name: Lone Grave
properties.Location: Hwy 20, 8 m. east of Nevada City
properties.Description: Julius Albert Apperson Born June 1855-Died May 6,1858. A pioneer who crossed the plains to California who died and was buried here. The Emigrant Trail followed along this ridge and through Nevada City. The marking of this lone grave perpetuates the memory of all lone graves throughout the state of California. Plaque incorrectly identifies this Landmark as NEV 001. Note: Julius Apperson was not a passerby. The boy died as the result of burns sustained on his parents' ranch and he was buried on Apperson property. The original date on the grave was May 31,1858. There are two white wooden grave markers nailed to trees behind the fenced-in gravesite. One says "In memory of Julius Albert Apperson, died May 6, 1858, age 2 years, 2 mos., 25 days." The other contains the boy's initials and dates. A gravestone on the ground inside the fence reads: In Loving Memory of Julius Albert Apperson, Died May 6, 1858, Age 2 yrs, 2 mos, 25 days." However, if that was his true age he would have been born in February 1856 instead of June 1855, as the plaque states. References; (1) Testimony of John Milton Apperson, a Tehama County cattleman and older brother of Julius, on February 25, 1936; (2) "Lone Graves of Nevada County" in the Nevada County Historical Society Bulletin, January 1961; (3) an item in the Nevada Democrat, May 5, 1858, stating that the child was terribly burned near the house where he lived on April 30.

properties.Name: La Grange Giant
properties.Location: Location: Next to museum in N. Bloomfield
properties.Description: This monitor was used at the now closed La Grange mine near Weaverville in Trinity County and is similar in size to those used at the Malakoff to wash down the gravel hillsides. Note: Historians still disagree over which mine was larger; the La Grange or the North Bloomfield.

properties.Name: Alvin Stevens Trivelpiece
properties.Location: At Diggins Overlook in Chute Hill campground about 7/10 m. east of North Bloomfield
properties.Description: Alvin Stevens Trivelpiece 1903-1967. Californian, Clamper, Nevada County Historian, Newspaperman, Friend and a Founding Father of the Malakoff State Park, in whose memory these benches were placed.

properties.Name: Relief Hill
properties.Location: South of intersection of Relief Hill Rd and Relief Hill Mine Rd, about 5 m. east of North Bloomfield
properties.Description: Note: Access to the old townsite and historic cemetery is sometimes restricted by the US Forest Service.  Description: Relief Hill dates from 1853. By 1856, it had a population of 75, two saloons, one store, one butcher shop, one blacksmith shop, two boarding houses and several homes. In 1858, registered voters alone numbered 100. Its decline followed the Sawyer decision enjoining certain aspects of hydraulic mining. In the early 1900s, some residents moved closer to Relief Hill Road. Some of those buildings can still be seen. While there is still some intermittent mining in the area, by the 1960s, the old townsite was largely deserted. Not much but the cemetery remains.

properties.Name: Graniteville
properties.Location: No. Bloomfield-Graniteville Rd, across from house at No. 35177. 50 ft past gazebo bearing Graniteville sign.
properties.Description: A camp established in this area in 1850 was called Eureka; then later, Eureka South. By 1856 it sometimes had a winter population of 1000. Rich placer mining deposits were played out by 1865, but quartz mining continued. By 1867, total gold taken from this area was estimated at 20 million dollars. Area also important as distribution point for water from reservoirs, fed to hydraulic mines below by ditches. Name changed to Graniteville when Post Office was established on Aug. 26, 1867.

properties.Name: Summit City/Meadow Lake
properties.Location: Meadow Lake Rd, south of Jackson Meadows Rd
properties.Description: In June of 1863, the trapper Henry Hartley discovered gold bearing ore here and staked out the Excelsior Company claims. Exaggerated reports and a 1865 market panic in the Comstock mines of Virginia City brought thousands of miners overnight to the supposed 'Little Comstock' of Summit City. Within two years an incorporated town, renamed Meadow Lake grew to encompass 160 acres with 4,000 summer residents and over 500 buildings, including 200 business houses, a stock exchange, daily newspaper, Post Office, school, 6 breweries and 80 saloons. Streets were laid out grid fashion, with a 9,000 square foot plaza on the lakeshore. An excursion vessel ferried revelers to four hurdy-gurdy houses at the lake’s upper end. The winter of 1866-1867 brought 30 feet of snow with the 'Snowshoe Express' delivering mail through Cisco. In all the eight stamp mills in a district of 10,910 claims failed to extract the expected gold from its 'Rebellious Ore.' The optimism faded and the town declined with like rapidity. July of 1869 found 60 residents. By 1873 only Hartley 'The Hermit' remained. His grave is on a hillside to the west of town. A wooden sign nearby was erected at an unknown date by Troop 40, Kentfield-Marin Council, Boy Scouts of America: Meadow Lake-Excelsior. The granite dam was built 1858 for flumes of valley gold towns. Called Summit City with 2000 pop. after 1866. It incorporated as Meadow Lake 1866. Because gold could not be separated it was abandoned 1872.

properties.Name: Emigrant Trail to Nevada City
properties.Location: Washington Ridge Vista Point, Hwy 20, 0.2 m. west of Washington Rd
properties.Description: In 1850, the year after the fabulous gold strike on Deer Creek in Nevada City, the Overland Emigrant Trail branched off the original Bear River route at this point on its way to Nevada City and the Sacramento Valley. Soon thereafter the trail became a toll road and later a public road. The deep vehicle ruts can still be seen as they cross and recross Highway 20 many times.

properties.Name: Town of Washington
properties.Location: Bottom of Washington Rd on South Fork of the Yuba River, 18 m. northeast of Nevada City via Hwy 20
properties.Description: Washington, originally Indiana Boys Camp, is a town that refused to ghost. It was settled in 1849. By 1880 miners had recovered over $10,500,000 in gold here. Note: First plaque is on the Washington Hotel. Note: The only mining town in the county not destroyed by fire. Today, Washington (pop. about 180) is one of the few remaining early mining towns. The permanent population swells to hundreds more residents in the summer months. A second plaque, shown above, was dedicated at an unknown date in a small park at the intersection of Washington Rd and Alpha Toll Rd: In August, 1850 Washington was the highest point on the South Yuba River at which gold had been discovered, with over a 1,000 miners. In 1870 the Chinese outnumbered the white population. The last try to strike it rich was in the 1890’s. Washington is the last remaining village of the many that flourished in the Washington Mining District. Historical notes by Robert I. and Grace I. Slyter.

properties.Name: Washington Hotel and Site
properties.Location: 15432 Washington Rd, town of Washington
properties.Description: Hessel Buisman built the first hotel on this site in 1857. It was destroyed by fire in August 1867, along with neighboring businesses. Buisman replaced it with a two-story hotel in that same year. In 1887, Buisman's daughter Harminia and her husband, E. T. Worthley, inherited the hotel, which burned in April 1896. The Worthleys reopened it with a third story in August 1896. John J. Rogers bought the hotel in 1910 for $50, and in 1911 he installed a water pipeline across the river to the Nice and Latta ditch to furnish water for the town. In 1912, he used the water to generate the first electricity for the hotel. Thomas B. Williamson, who had purchased a half interest in the hotel for $10 in 1911, bought out Rogers in 1916, and then sold it to Pietro Orzalli. Orzalli sold the property to R. F. Williamson (brother of Tom) in 1925. In 1926, Emory J. Haverstock bought the hotel and added dormer windows on the top floor, using lumber salvaged from the fire-ravaged Dugan Hotel (also in Washington). Haverstock sold it to Clark and Edna Waite for $10 in 1939. In 1955, the hotel was sold for $10 to Harold Moneyhun, former owner of the Holbrooke Hotel in Grass Valley, and Edwin Furano of Nevada City. In 1968, Thomas E. Walsh used siding salvaged from the National Hotel Annex in Nevada City to enclose the side porch on the upriver side of the hotel.

properties.Name: Brimskill Building
properties.Location: Washington Rd, opposite hotel in town of Washington
properties.Description: Built by Edward Brimskill, 1849-1851. Rear section built 1849. Iron shutters a protection from fire and robbers, imported from Scotland. Used in early days as general store and miners supply. Wells Fargo maintained desk room here for many years and shipped thousands of dollars of gold from here. One of the best preserved buildings in California of the gold rush era. Said to be oldest building in Nevada County.

properties.Name: Kohler Building
properties.Location: Washington Rd, next to hotel in town of Washington
properties.Description: Built by Henry Kohler, pioneer merchant and miner born in Germany in 1825. He came to Washington from Indiana in 1854. He mined until 1861 when he opened a general merchandise store to supply groceries, hardware and mining supplies to the area.

properties.Name: Washington Elementary School
properties.Location: School St in town of Washington
properties.Description: 100 Years of uninterrupted use as a California public school. Having survived fires, floods, wars, time, and politics, this school has been doing its part to ensure the rights of American children to receive a basic education.

properties.Name: Canyon Creek Bridge Site
properties.Location: Maybert Rd at Canyon Creek, 3.3 m. east of town of Washington. Maybert Rd does not require four-wheel-drive but is not advised for cars with low clearance
properties.Description: The Canyon Creek Bridge was built in 1895 by Cotton Brothers and Co. of Oakland, California, for $1,725. Completed two years earlier than the Old Auburn Bridge (No. 13,), it is of similar construction and design. Underneath it is the reservoir that supplies water to the residents of the town of Washington. Canyon Creek is a major tributary of the South Yuba River, and the scenic view of the rapids and falls above the bridge is outstanding. Note: After determining the bridge had outlived its useful life, the County erected a modern bridge in 2017 and placed this plaque: Site of a steel pony truss bridge erected in 1895 at Canyon Creek Crossing on the road linking Washington to the town of Maybert. There the Yuba Mine employed 13 Chinese and 27 Americans, one of the few mines still employing Chinese. In the 1880’s and 1890’s Maybert had a Post Office, store, boarding house, school and saloon. Fire destroyed all 20 of its dwellings in 1909. The old bridge was disassembled and is awaiting relocation by Nevada City as part of its hiking trails expansion.

properties.Name: Ormonde Town Site
properties.Location: Maybert Rd, 3.6 m. east of Washington. About 3/10 m. past Maybert (Canyon Creek) bridge in Golden Quartz campground. Maybert Rd does not require 4-wheel-drive but not advised for cars with low clearance.
properties.Description: The town of Ormonde was established here in 1887. Downstream, across the mouth of Canyon Creek was Canyonville 1850, and upriver approximately four miles was Maybert 1886. These towns were part of the upper Washington Mining District and were the furthest upstream of the serious mining ventures along the South Yuba. During its brief history the district yielded 17 million dollars in gold, but by 1897 it was nearly totally abandoned. The remains have since been obliterated by flooding. Note: The town consisted of 8-10 buildings, including a store, saloon and boarding house.

properties.Name: Alpha and Omega Hydraulic
properties.Location: Hwy 20, About 16 m. east of Nevada City and 10 m. west of I-80 Hwy junction. Near eastern end of restrooms in Omega Rest Area
properties.Description: One mile north of here were the towns of Alpha and Omega, named by gold miners in the early 1850’s. The tremendous hydraulic diggings, visible from near this point, engulfed most of the original townsites. Alpha was the birthplace of famed opera singer Emma Nevada. Mining at Omega continued until 1949, and lumbering operations are carried on there today.

properties.Name: Gaston
properties.Location: Roughly midway between Graniteville and town of Washington, near the intersection of Gaston and Hoosier Rds, in the Tahoe National Forest.
properties.Description: A historic mining community. Placer mining around Gaston began in the early 1850’s. The first hard rock mine, the California Mine, was established in 1856. An ample supply of water was ensured by the arrival of the North Bloomfield ditch in 1870. In 1898, the mine, now known as the Gaston Mine, was acquired by the San Francisco based Gaston Gold Mining Company, which substantially upgraded operations. A town blossomed around the mine. The population was recorded as about 200 in 1900. There was stage service to the town of Washington, and to Nevada City. By 1904, the town boasted two stores, a hotel, a saloon, a hardware store, a Post Office, a water system, electric lights, a telephone line to Nevada City, a fire company and a school. The mine closed during World War I, because of a shortage of labor and supplies needed for the war effort. There was intermittent mining after the war. By the 1940s’, the last remaining building was in shambles. Today, nothing readily visible remains of Gaston.

properties.Name: Western America Skisport Museum
properties.Location: Exit on Boreal Ridge Rd on I-80 west of summit
properties.Description: A monument and statue was placed by Snowshoe Thompson Lodge No. 78, Sons of Norway, Yuba City: Snowshoe Thompson. A hero of the Sierra Nevada mountains! Probably the first skier of the West. This Viking Son of Norway exemplified the spirit of a true pioneer: Strong, daring, faithful and courageous. He was the answer to CaliforniaÍs motto, 'Bring me men to match my mountains.' For 20 years he was the winter lifeline between the new state of California and the East with a regular mail schedule between Placerville, California, and Genoa, Nevada, and other isolated hamlets of the Mother Lode country. Mail, news of the world, medicine, supplies and equipment arrived on the sturdy shoulders of this giant Snow Viking over great snowdrifts, through raging winter storms, with packs of up to 100 pounds, he made his 'appointed rounds.' His daring rescues, errands of mercy, and many kindnesses made him a legend in his own time. He was born John Tostensen at Tinn in Telemark, Norway, April 30, 1827. He died May 15, 1876, at the age of 49. He rests at the base of the mountains he loved, by the side of his wife and son in the cemetery at Genoa, Nevada. A simple headstone, engraved with a pair of skis, marks his grave.

properties.Name: Trans-Sierra Freeway Project
properties.Location: Highway rest stops on both sides of I-80, at Donner Summit, west of Truckee
properties.Description: Plaque dedicated 1966 by the American Society of Civil Engineering: Civil Engineering Achievement of Merit, 1966, Awarded by the American Society of Civil Engineers.

properties.Name: McGlashan Point
properties.Location: Overlook next to Donner Summit Bridge on Donner Pass Rd, Old Hwy 40
properties.Description: Dedicated August 10,1986 in honor of Charles Fayette McGlashan 1847-1931. Truckee’s Patriarch, Historian, Author, Editor, Attorney, Legislator, Inventor, Entomologist and Astronomer. His last public address was given in 1926 at the Donner Summit Bridge Dedication. This site is named in his memory by the people of Truckee.

properties.Name: Donner Summit Bridge
properties.Location: Donner Pass Rd (Old Hwy 40) overlooking Donner Lake
properties.Description: First plaque dedicated 1926 by Native Sons of the Golden West: Dedicated to the pioneers who blazed the Overland Trail through these mountains. Built by the U. S. Bureau of Public Roads and the California Highway Commission, 1925-1926. Landmark registered and second plaque dedicated 1998 by Nevada County: 1926 Donner Summit Bridge Restored 1995. Note: In 1926 it was anticipated that the bridge (built at a cost of about $40,000) would become a popular stopping place on the "Victory Highway." The bridge was designed by Norman C. Raab, whose wife, Ruby Bishop Raab, was the great-granddaughter of Isaac Hitchcock of the Stephens-Townsend-Murphy party. The original bridge arch was 110 feet long and 70 feet high, built on a compound curve, with a seven percent grade. Among those who attended the 1926 ceremony were Charles F. McGlashan and these descendants of Donner party survivors: James Fraser Lewis, Martha Jane Lewis, Susan A. Lewis, and Ernest H. Murphy. Norman Raab also designed the world-famous Bixby Creek Bridge on State Highway 1 at Big Sur, built in 1930-1931.

properties.Name: Mt. Elisha Stephens
properties.Location: Parking lot next to Donner Summit Bridge on Donner Pass Rd, Old Hwy 40
properties.Description: Stephens-Townsend-Murphy Party of 1844 First Pioneer Wagons Over the Sierra Nevada. On May 22, 1844, this small wagon party of 50 men, women and children 'jumped off' from Council Bluffs, Iowa, bound for California. These courageous pioneers were the first emigrants to take wagons over the Sierra Nevada, opening the Truckee Route of the California Trail. The Murphy, Townsend, Miller, and Hitchcock families formed the main groups of the party. Caleb Greenwood was the hired guide, and Elisha Stephens was elected Captain of the wagon train. After following the Oregon Trail to Fort Hall, Idaho, they turned away from the well-worn path and headed west into the unfamiliar Nevada desert. A Paiute Indian Chief showed them how to reach a river flowing from the Sierra Nevada, which they named 'Truckee' in his honor. Overcoming severe conditions, they followed the Truckee River to the base of the Sierra. Six members, on horseback, continued to follow the Truckee River and eventually arrived safely at Sutter's New Helvetia on December 10, 1844. Six of the wagons were left in the charge of two men, and young Moses Schallenberger, near Truckee Lake (present Donner Lake). Near this spot, with two feet of snow on the ground, they worked the remaining five wagons across the summit of the mighty Sierra Nevada on November 25, 1844. Deepening snow forced them to camp near Big Bend, on the South Yuba River. Leaving the wagons with two men and the women and children, the remaining 17 men continued on to New Helvetia to seek help. Somehow, John Sutter persuaded the men to enlist in his forces taking part in a Mexican civil war. Eventually the families were reunited, and all members (including two babies born on the way) arrived safely at Sutter’s Fort in early March 1845. Note: Mount Elisha Stephens is west of bridge on north side of road.

properties.Name: China Wall at Donner Summit
properties.Location: South side of Donner Pass Rd (Old Hwy 40), west of Donner Lake about 0.5 m. below summit
properties.Description: Charles Crocker, construction chief of the Central Pacific Railroad (CPRR), contracted for a workforce of approximately 12,000 Chinese laborers to push the CPRR tracks over its Trans-Sierra crossing on its race east to meet with the Union Pacific at Promontory, Utah Territory. A railroad retaining wall and fill, constructed of Sierra granite, stand silently above on the pass as a lasting monument to these Asian 'Master Builders' who left an indelible mark on the history of California and the West.

properties.Name: First Wagons Across the Sierra
properties.Location: West end Donner Lake, corner Donner Pass Rd and S. Shore Dr, west of Truckee
properties.Description: The Stephens-Townsend-Murphy Party, with guidance from old Caleb Greenwood and Chief Truckee, brought their wagons up the Truckee River bed and on Nov. 25,1844, 191 days out of Council Bluffs, Iowa, passed this point and crossed the mighty Sierra summit directly to the west, blazing the famous California Emigrant Trail for all who followed.

properties.Name: Pollard's Station
properties.Location: Near intersection of S. Shore Dr and Donner Pass Rd, west of Truckee
properties.Description: On this site, Joseph Delos Pollard constructed the first resort on the west end of Donner Lake. Between mid 1864 and early 1868 Pollard’s Station on the Dutch Flat & Donner Lake Wagon Road was office to the Pioneer Stage Co. and Wells, Fargo & Co. Express, as well as a hotel, boasting bar room, reading room, billiards and a bowling alley. Visitors could rent boats, horses or carriages to enjoy the scenic grandeur. The station was ravaged by fire twice and rebuilt once. The station was no longer needed due to the completion of the railroad in June 1868, which put a virtual end to wagon and stage traffic across the Sierra.

properties.Name: Schallenberger Cabin Site
properties.Location: In Donner Memorial State Park, about 75 yds. east of Museum
properties.Description: Near this spot stood a small cabin built by 18-year old Moses Schallenberger and two other men. They were members of the Stephens-Townsend-Murphy party of 1844, the first pioneers to take wagons over the Sierra Nevada, opening the Truckee Route of the California Trail. The three men had volunteered to remain behind and guard six of the wagons left here by the main party. Due to extreme winter weather conditions and lack of food, the three men agreed to separate. The two older men rejoined the wagon party, but due to his weakened physical condition, Moses Schallenberger chose to remain at the cabin. The young man survived for nearly three months alone in the small cabin during the winter of 1844-45 before being rescued. His cabin would later provide shelter for the Breen family, members of the ill-fated Donner Party, who were stranded here in 1846-47. The courage and resolution of Moses Schallenberger during his solitary winter ordeal in this cabin makes him one of the true heroes in the saga of the California Trail. This monument was made possible through the generosity of many groups and individuals committed to the preservation of the California Trail. Note: The monument contains a time capsule to be opened on August 19, 2095.

properties.Name: Emigrant Trail on Coldstream Road
properties.Location: West side of Cold Stream Rd, 800 ft south of Donner Pass Rd, just past Cold Stream Day Use sign, Truckee
properties.Description: The Emigrant Trail in the pioneer days of California turned to the south at this point for approximately three miles, then went across the summit of the Sierras about a mile south of the present railroad. It was here that the Donner Party missed the trail owing to the early snows, resulting in the tragedy.

properties.Name: Donner Party - Graves Cabin Site
properties.Location: Opposite 12020 Donner Pass Rd in West Truckee
properties.Description: Plaque dedicated 1919 by Native Sons of the Golden West: Donner Party 1846-1847. On this spot stood the Graves Cabin.

properties.Name: Gateway Cabin
properties.Location: 10115 Donner Trail Rd, Truckee
properties.Description: This cabin was one of several built by Jack Wolert for Dick Joseph in 1939 on US Route 40. The cabin was constructed of lumber salvaged from houses being dismantled five miles north of Truckee at Hobart Mills and served as the Gateway Motel’s office. Originally located at the site of the current Gateway Shopping Center on Donner Pass Road (historic US 40). It was donated to the Truckee Donner Historical Society in 1990 and moved to this location on May 23, 1991. Thanks to community efforts, the cabin has been restored and serves as a historical research library.

properties.Name: Hooligan Rock
properties.Location: 11200 Donner Pass Rd, east end of parking lot
properties.Description: Behind this broken rock, vigilante justice in the form of a tar and feather party or other form of physical punishment was meted out to the villains and ruffians who plagued Truckee through the dawn of the 20th-century. Constable Jacob Teeter bravely fought against vigilantism and his friend, attorney C. F. McGlashan, blasted the rock, ending its symbolism of terror, and used parts of the rock in a wall around his mansion. His granddaughter, Nona, recalled that the rock formed a 'backdrop of ugly secret scenes, floggings in the night, scalding tar and a smother of feathers, curses and screams for mercy.

properties.Name: Sierra Sun (Truckee Republican)
properties.Location: 10775 Pioneer Trail, Pioneer Commerce Center, Truckee
properties.Description: Oldest continuous business enterprise in the Central Sierra commenced publication in 1869 as the 'Truckee Republican' and was also informally known as the 'Truckee Screwdriver.' The definitive 'History of the Donner Party' was first published in this newspaper in 1879 when author, teacher, statesman C. F. McGlashan was its editor. Note: The Truckee Republican, which began life as the Grass Valley Republican, commenced publishing at Truckee in 1872, not 1869. Its descendant is now the Sierra Sun. The plaque was moved in 2014 from 12315 Deerfield Drive, and cannot currently be located.

properties.Name: Donner Camp at Alder Creek Valley
properties.Location: Alder Creek Picnic Site; 2.75 m. north of 1-80 on Hwy 89, 0.1 m. east of Hwy 89, Truckee
properties.Description: This site has three plaques and was designated a National Historical Landmark in 1966. First plaque dedicated 1996 by Tahoe National Forest: In the fall of 1846, 25 members of the Donner Party became trapped by an early snowstorm here at Alder Creek Valley. The George and Jacob Donner families, their teamsters, and fellow travelers suffered extreme hardship and starvation. They spent the winter here cut off from the rest of their party who camped at Donner Lake. Only eleven survived the ordeal. Their survival, against desperate odds, stands as a testament to the enduring pioneer spirit that helped shape the future of California.Second plaque dedicated 1996 by Chap 3691 E Clampus Vitus: They gave unselfishly, their fortunes and their lives that their children should survive. Near this site, in the winter of 1846, two pioneer women gave up their lives for their families. Tamsen and Elizabeth Donner feared their many children could not survive the ravages of cold and starvation when the party was caught in an early blizzard. They provided care and comfort to their families and companions throughout the snowbound winter, desperately trying to prevent the death of their loved ones. Both lost their lives. However, most of their children survived to carry their mothers' dreams of new life and new beginnings to the valleys of California. The summit that they never crossed now bears the family name. An inspiration to all who followed their footsteps across the Sierra Nevada Mountains, we herein honor the memory and the sacrifices of these women. Their struggle to survive, enduring hardships we can barely imagine, remains a legacy of the pioneer spirit. On this 150th anniversary of their tragic encampment the Chief Truckee Chapter of E Clampus Vitus dedicates this monument to their spirit and the preservation of their memory that we not forget the sacrifices they made in opening California to its destiny.The Donner Camp Site plaque is located in the middle of the Donner Camp Interpretive Trail, just past the end of the boardwalk.Second plaque dedicated 1960 by Chap 10 E Clampus Vitus, Historical Society, Tahoe National Forest USFS, Truckee-Donner Chamber of Commerce, and Native Daughters of the Golden West: On October 28, 1846 the six covered wagons brought west by George and Jacob Donner and their families halted here for repairs. By March of 1847 one half of the party of 22 adults and children had died of starvation and cold. They came west seeking a new life and found misery and death.

properties.Name: Hobart Mills Site
properties.Location: Just east of Hwy 89, five miles north of Truckee. There are two plaques, about 200 yards apart
properties.Description: First plaque dedicated 1938 by descendants of Walter Scott Hobart is about 0.2 m. north of the junction of Hobart Mills Rd with Old Hwy 89 on west side of Old 89: This monument marks the townsite of Hobart Mills, California. A logging and lumbering enterprise of sixty-six years life in the Sierra Nevada mountains it commemorates and honors its founder Walter Scott Hobart 1839-1892 and those whose loyalty, industry and ability made its successful operation possible.

properties.Name: Donner Memorial State Park
properties.Location: 12593 Donner Pass Rd, Truckee. In addition to the Museum, the Park contains three monuments.
properties.Description: The Origin Of The Park. Joseph Marzen sold one acre of land east of Donner Lake to Charles F. McGlashan for the purpose of erecting a monument to the Donner Party. McGlashan then sold the land to the Native Sons of the Golden West (NSGW) for $1.00 in August of 1909. At the center of the acre, according to McGlashan, was the site of the Breen Cabin, where the monument would be situated. On June 6, 1918, the NSGW dedicated the completed Pioneer Memorial. California Governor William D. Stephens signed legislation acquiring 'Donner Monument and lands contingent thereto.' On May 23, 1928, the Grand Parlor of the Native Sons of the Golden West conveyed eleven acres of land to the People of the State of California. The deed for the parcel adjacent to the Lincoln Highway included one provision: 'The tract of land above described shall be known and designated as the Donner State Monument and shall be a memorial to the California Pioneers of the Overland Trail’. Note: The plaque is inside the building, to the left as you enter.

properties.Name: Murphy Cabin
properties.Location: In Donner Memorial State Park, a few hundred yds south of Museum on trail
properties.Description: The face of this rock formed the north end and the fireplace of the Murphy Cabin. General Stephen W. Kearney, on June 22, 1847, buried under the middle of the cabin the bodies found in the vicinity. Following is a complete list of members of the Donner party who occupied the various cabins and tents.This and the other Donner campsites were designated a National Historical Landmark in 1961. Placed on the National Register.

properties.Name: Donner Emigrant Trail
properties.Location: Front of Tahoe Truckee High School, 11725  Donner Pass Rd, Truckee
properties.Description: The Emigrant Trail in the Pioneer Days of California came through the low pass to the north, facing this monument. The Trail turned west at this point for a distance of twenty-six hundred feet where a tablet describes the route then followed. Adjoining plaque dedicated 2014: First Permanent Emigrant Trail Markers. The nearby monument was envisioned in 1929 by C.F. McGlashan, Truckee’s foremost resident 1872-1931 and author of the 1880 classic, The History of the Donner Party; P.M. Weddell, who placed wooden signs on the Donner Trail from Verdi, Nevada over Coldstream Pass to Lake Mary from 1924 until his death in 1951; and W.F. Knowland, U. S. Senator (1945-1959) and the chairman of The Native Sons of the Golden West’s Landmark Commission. The three trail authorities met in McGlashan’s law office in Truckee to draw up the text for the plaque on this monument, listed as #3 on the 1930 Weddell map to the right and a companion plaque for the monument listed as #5 located one half mile to the west on old Hwy 40 and Coldstream Road. Note: According to the P. M. Weddell map of the Historic Emigrant Road, this resting place of the Native Sons' marker is close to its original location.

properties.Name: Hobart Mills Site Second Plaque
properties.Location: About 200 yards from 172
properties.Description: Walter Scott Hobart's Sierra Nevada Wood & Lumber Company moved machinery, buildings and railroad equipment here from Lake Tahoe in 1896. The town and business flourished for 40 years, ceasing operations in 1936. Fibreboard Corporation operated a mill and railroad here from 1946 to 1955, logging timber purchased from Southern Pacific. The old mill was burned in 1964. Hobart Mills was an important lumbering center and a major contributor to the heritage of the Eastern Sierra.
