properties.Name: Donner or Pioneer Monument
properties.Location: In Donner Memorial State Park, about 100 yds. east of Museum
properties.Description: Monument dedicated and first two plaques placed 1918 by the Governors of California and Nevada, three survivors of the Donner Party, and Native Daughters of the Golden West. First plaque: Virile to risk and find, Kindly withal and a ready help. Facing the brunt of fate. Indomitable-unafraid." Second plaque: In commemoration of the pioneers who crossed the plains to settle in California. Landmark registered and third plaque placed 1962 by State of California, CHL 134: Donner Party. Near this spot stood the Breen Cabin of the party of emigrants who started for California from Springfield, Illinois, in April, 1846, under the leadership of Captain George Donner. Delays occurred and when the party reached this locality, on October 29, the Truckee Pass emigrant road was concealed by snow. The height of the shaft of the monument indicates the depth of the snow, which was twenty-two feet. After futile efforts to cross the summit the party was compelled to encamp for the winter. The Graves cabin was situated about three- quarters of a mile to the eastward, the Murphy cabin was about two hundred yards southwest of the monument, and the Donner tents were at the head of Alder Creek. Ninety people were in the party and forty-two perished, most of them from starvation and exposure.

properties.Name: Kruger-White House
properties.Location: 10292 Donner Pass Rd, Truckee
properties.Description: Designated a National Historic Landmark 1982: This property Kruger-White House has been placed on the National Register of Historic Places by the United States Department of the Interior. Note: W. H. Kruger, a lumberman and entrepreneur, built this impressive home 107 years ago. Mr. Kruger contributed significantly to the 19th century community development of Truckee as one of the town's leading commercial pioneers. Mr. C. B. White, a banker, bought the house in 1904. Today, the Kruger-White home stands as an historic architectural landmark in a town which, for over a century, has represented an important gateway to California.

properties.Name: Truckee Jail
properties.Location: Northeast corner of Spring and Jibboom Sts, Truckee
properties.Description: 1875 Old Truckee Jail. Built in September 1875 and in continuous use until 1964. Landmark registered and second plaque dedicated 1971 by Nevada County, NEV 04: The first extension of the Nevada County jail which was built in 1875 by order of the County Supervisors on the petition of residents in Meadow Lake and Truckee townships due to the high cost of transporting prisoners from the eastern part of the county to the jail in Nevada City. Built of stone at a cost of $2,500 the building housed its first prisoner in September 1875.  Note: Building now houses the Truckee-Donner Historical Museum.

properties.Name: Rocking Stone
properties.Location: Between High St and Keiser Ave, near Spring St, Truckee
properties.Description: A natural glacial formation, or the work of an unknown tribe as a form of altar. Its exact origin will never be known. The perfectly balanced stone until recently would rock at the touch of a finger. C. F. McGlashan built the original tower in 1895 and used it to display Donner Party relics and his famous butterfly collection. Site of an overnight stop for the Olympic Torch in 1960.

properties.Name: The Tin Can -- Dot's
properties.Location: 10116 and 10098 Jibboom St, Truckee
properties.Description: The two modern buildings replaced structures built in the early 20th-century and used in two of Truckee’s notorious industries: bootlegging and prostitution. They upheld a tradition begun on this street in the 1870’s. Many a thirst was slaked and need fulfilled because of these buildings' contents. Politely ignored, although they never failed because of lack of business, they operated until mid-century to serve the working men of this and surrounding communities. Changing commercial interests and ultimately property values doomed these buildings to history.

properties.Name: Old Stone Garage
properties.Location: Southwest corner Jibboom and Bridge Sts, Truckee
properties.Description: Truckee’s Old Stone Garage and Site of Town’s First Dwelling. In 1863, Joseph Gray built Truckee's first structure on this site for use as the Dutch Flat-Donner Lake Wagon Road's toll station. The old log structure was moved in 1907 to the Englehart property on Church Street, one block east of this site, where it still stands and the Brethren of ECV dedicated a plaque in 1965. In 1909, D. J. Smith, with the help of European-trained stone masons, constructed the present building for use as a livery and garage.

properties.Name: Jibboom Street
properties.Location: Southwest corner Jibboom and Bridge Sts, Truckee. The stone and bronze plaque have been removed and are awaiting rededication
properties.Description: Wooden plaque dedicated and placed in Pastime Club Bar 1969. Bronze plaque rededicated and placed in present location 1979  by Chap 3691 E Clampus Vitus: Jibboom Street. Sierra Site of the World’s Oldest Profession 1867-1949.

properties.Name: Truckee's First Log Cabin
properties.Location: 10030 Church St, Truckee
properties.Description: First Log Cabin. Erected by Joseph Gray at S.W. corner of present day Bridge and Spring streets to serve Dutch Flat Wagon Road traffic over Donner Pass. Removed to this site 1907.

properties.Name: Truckee Round House Site
properties.Location: East end of municipal parking lot, just west of 10021 Donner Pass Rd, Truckee
properties.Description: Needed to house and maintain the engines of the Central Pacific Railroad during construction of the trans-Sierra crossing, an enclosed wooden round house was constructed here in 1868. It was razed by fire in March of 1869. A 16-stall wooden structure was built that year as the maintenance facility of the C.P.R.R., Truckee Division. Another fire in 1876 resulted in construction of a 22-stall granite and wooden structure. This served through 1942, when it was officially retired, a victim of the end of the steam era and consolidation of maintenance at other locations. The round houses were home to helper engines, fire trains and the first rotary snow plow in the Sierra.

properties.Name: First Transcontinental Railroad--Truckee
properties.Location: Track side of Amtrak station, 10065 Donner Pass Rd, Truckee
properties.Description: While construction on Sierra tunnels delayed Central Pacific, advance forces at Truckee began building forty miles of track east and west of Truckee, moving all supplies by wagon and sled. Summit Tunnel was opened in December, 1867. The line reached Truckee April 3, 1868, and the Sierra was conquered. Rails reached Reno June 19, and construction advanced eastward one mile daily toward the meeting with Union Pacific at Promontory May 10,1869, to complete the first transcontinental railroad.

properties.Name: Theodore Dehone Judah
properties.Location: Track side of Amtrak station, 10065 Donner Pass Rd, Truckee
properties.Description: As Chief Engineer of the Central Pacific Railroad, Judah's engineering skill, political savvy and financial genius, along with the promoters' capital, culminated in the formation and construction of the Trans-Sierra leg of the first transcontinental railroad. While fighting the excesses of the railroadÍs promoters, he died without seeing his dream completed.

properties.Name: Truckee Flag Pole
properties.Location: 10065 Donner Pass Rd, northwest side of Amtrak station, Truckee
properties.Description: Truckee / Jewel of the Eastern Sierras. First known as Gray's Toll Station, then Coburn's Station, Truckee was established in 1863. Renowned for its lumber industry, transcontinental railroad, icehouses, saloons and red light district, Truckee has never been known for her laid back demeanor. It has always been a town where people came to entertain themselves on Friday and Saturday nights, just as it is today. Second plaque dedicated 1994 by Truckee Fire Protection District: Truckee Fire Protection District. This flagpole represents 100 years of service by the Truckee Fire Protection District and its members, past and present for their commitment to the preservation of life and property.

properties.Name: Old Capitol Building
properties.Location: 10072 Donner Pass Rd, Truckee
properties.Description: The Old Capitol. Erected in 1870. In its heyday it was the social center of Truckee . . . Many of the leading thespians . . . politicians . . . and other celebrities of that era gathered here . . . Note: This plaque has disappeared. A plaque placed on the front of building by unknown persons reads: Capitol Building 1870 Truckee California. The first brick building in Truckee, it was originally Hurd's Saloon, then the Capitol Saloon, later used by the Piper Opera Company and the County Court.

properties.Name: Truckee's Vigilance ("601") Committee
properties.Location: On sidewalk in front of 10096 Donner Pass Rd, across street from Amtrak Station, Truckee
properties.Description: Truckee’s vigilance committee, known as the 601, was born in response to the rise in crime and 'undesirables' which plagued the young railroad town. In late 1874 and early 1875, the 601 carried out a campaign to intimidate and rid the town of those elements. After accidentally shooting one of their own members, the 601 disbanded until August 1889 when they reassembled for one last time. Though their goals were never fully achieved, the 601 did bring a semblance of law and order to the area through their vigilance.

properties.Name: George Schaffer
properties.Location: Star Hotel, 10015 West River St. Truckee
properties.Description: One of Truckee’s earliest settlers, Schaffer in 1866 built the first lumber mill in the town. He freighted the locomotive 'San Mateo' to Truckee in a winter crossing of the Sierra prior to the laying of Central Pacific tracks. This building 'The Star Hotel' was built by Schaffer probably for his family. When mill operations were relocated up Martis Creek in 1871, this building was converted to a hotel and has remained in continuous operation to this day. For 24 years, the Truckee Basin supplied timber to railroads, mines and boom towns through 'Uncle George's' enterprises. Note: The Schaffer family cemetery, located at 10233 Schaffer Dr., may be visited by the public.

properties.Name: Old Chinese Herb Shop
properties.Location: Corner of S.E. River St. and Brockway Rd., Truckee
properties.Description: Old Chinatown. Construction of the Central Pacific Railroad over Donner Summit brought thousands of Chinese laborers here in 1868. They used ‘squatter's rights' to build a ramshackle colony along the Truckee River on what is now River Avenue East. A huge fire destroyed Chinatown on May 29, 1875, but the Orientals rebuilt their community. Finally, on Nov. 18, 1878, a group of about 500 citizens, under the leadership of the Caucasian League, tore down the shanty town and ordered the 1000 or more Chinese to leave. They simply moved across the river, adjoining this former site of a Chinese herb shop, and built anew. A third fire, on Jan. 3, 1883, consumed the 'new' Chinatown and brought about the gradual end to the Chinese colony here. Bronze plaque dedicated 1980 by Chap 3691 E Clampus Vitus. Text of bronze plaque: Old Chinese Herb Shop.

properties.Name: Chief Truckee
properties.Location: Truckee River Regional Park, Hwy. 267, 1 m. south of Truckee
properties.Description: Chief Truckee. The legendary Paiute leader; friend and guide to pioneers; breveted a 'Captain' by John C. Fremont; gave his name to this valley, river and town; died near Dayton, Nevada, in 1860.

properties.Name: Sierra Mountain Cemetery
properties.Location: East end of E. Jibboom St, Truckee
properties.Description: The Masonic and Odd Fellows lodges each established cemeteries here in 1869 or 1870 to provide a burial place for their deceased. Catholics established a cemetery to the southwest. Pioneers and prominent citizens were buried within the original cemetery grounds. The less reputable were buried outside the fences. Stories abound of the bodies placed in snowbanks or ice houses awaiting the ground thaw. The Truckee Cemetery District was formed in 1946 and received title to the land and named the cemetery in 1964. In 1954 the original site increased in size despite the best efforts of the community to prevent the townfolk from dying.

properties.Name: Victory Highway Monument
properties.Location: Northwest corner of Spring St and Donner Pass Rd, Truckee
properties.Description: First plaque dedicated 1928. Text of plaque: Dedicated to California’s sons and daughters who served their country in the World War 1917-1918 and to the memory of those who gave the last full measure of devotion. Second plaque and monument dedicated 1998 by Truckee Town Council and California Department of Transportation: Victory Highway Monument Rededication July 24, 1998. This monument was originally sited on old Highway 40 near the California/Nevada line in 1928 and removed in the mid 1970s due to vandalism. It was one of a series of monuments placed on the 'Victory Highway' across the U.S., honoring those who died serving the United States in World War I. Donner Pass Road and part of Glenshire Drive through Truckee still follow the basic alignment of the old highway. The Town of Truckee, in cooperation with CalTrans, has rededicated this monument not only for its original purpose and the history of Old Highway 40, but also for current revitalization efforts occurring in historic downtown Truckee.

properties.Name: Commercial Row / Brickelltown Historic District
properties.Location: Downtown Truckee
properties.Description: The Commercial Row/ Brickelltown Historic District lies in the center of Truckee along the tracks of the first transcontinental railroad. It includes the first built areas of Truckee. Because of fires, most of the buildings in the district range from 1870 to the 1920s. The district illustrates Truckee's relationship with the railroad and the lumber industry and Truckee's appearance more than 100-years ago. Truckee was originally called Coburn Station, and then renamed around 1868 after a Paiute chief. The District was dedicated in 2009 by the Truckee Town Council.

properties.Name: Lake Tahoe Railway & Transportation Company Site
properties.Location: Just east of 10130 W. River St, across the railroad tracks from Amtrak station. The plaque is missing. If you have any information about its whereabouts, please contact the publisher.
properties.Description: The Lake Tahoe Railway & Transportation Company was incorporated on December 1898 by Duane Leroy Bliss. The Narrow Gauge Railroad opened for seasonal traffic on May 1, 1900. The line ran from the Southern Pacific Depot in Truckee, 15 miles south to the shores of Lake Tahoe. Tahoe City hosted the railroad’s shops. The Tahoe Tavern hotel and pier where the train met the Bliss steamer - Tahoe. Southern Pacific Purchased the line and converted it to standard gauge in 1926. Passenger Service operated until abandonment in November 1943.

properties.Name: Stampede Circle of Stones
properties.Location: 10600 Brockway Rd, northeast corner of Truckee River Regional Park, Truckee
properties.Description: The Stampede Circle of Stones is the oldest manmade structure in the Truckee region-at least 500 years old. Built by the Washoe or their predecessors, the Martis people, the Circle's original home was in Stampede Valley, about 10 miles northeast of here. In 1969 it was moved to this location shortly before the construction of the Stampede Dam flooded the valley. Archaeological digging on the original site indicates it may have been used as an antelope corral.

properties.Name: Boca Dam - Newlands Reclamation Project
properties.Location: East end of Boca Dam, Stampede Road 1 m. north of I-80, about 5 m. east of Truckee
properties.Description: Designated a National Historic Landmark 1981: Boca Dam 1937-1940. United States Department of the Interior, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary; Bureau of Reclamation, John C. Page, Commissioner; R. F. Walter, Chief Engineer; L. J. Foster and C. S. Hale, Construction Engineers. Height 116 feet, Length 1629 feet, Storage capacity 40,901 acre-feet. Contractor, George W. Condon Co. Note: Originally called the Truckee-Carson Project, the Newlands Project covers a large area in western Nevada and a smaller area of Truckee-Tahoe area. One of five authorized by the Federal Reclamation Act of 1902, to reclaim arid lands for agricultural purposes. Renamed in 1919 in honor of U.S. Senator Francis G. Newlands of Nevada, water from natural flow and storage in Lake Tahoe and Boca Reservoir is diverted from Truckee River into the 32.5-mile Truckee Canal and then discharged into the Carson River.

properties.Name: Boca Brewery
properties.Location: East end of Boca Dam, 1 m. north of 1-80 on Stampede Rd, about 5 m. east of Truckee
properties.Description: Boca. Noted as a railroad, ice and lumbering center since 1867 but most fondly remembered and hereby honored as home of the Boca Brewery which was located 1/2 mile south of this point across the Truckee River. Boca Lager Beer was world famous and mercifully slaked the thirst of a grateful mankind. Second plaque placed 2001 by Chap 3691 E Clampus Vitus: Boca Beer. Warranted to keep in any weather.

properties.Name: Boca Ice Harvest Site
properties.Location: Stampede Rd, 2 m. north of 1-80, 5 m. east of Truckee
properties.Description: From 1868 to 1927 huge quantities of ice were harvested from the Truckee Basin. This provided employment and significantly contributed to the area’s economic growth and its colorful history. Boca Pond was one of the first to be used to harvest ice and ship it across the nation. It was one of the last of the ice plants to survive competition from artificial ice companies.

properties.Name: Clinton Narrow Gauge Railroad
properties.Location: Southeast corner of Hirschdale Rd, and Juniper Way, about 5 m. east of Truckee and 1 m. south of I-80
properties.Description: First steam railroad logging operation in the Truckee River Basin. Commenced operation in the late 1870’s under the supervision of Fred Burckhalter, head of the Pacific Lumber and Wood Co. Line extended 10 miles along Juniper Creek with hope of eventual service to Lake Tahoe. Line abandoned in 1901 after several conflagrations at the PL&W Co. mill in Clinton.

properties.Name: Floriston (Bronco Site)
properties.Location: Eastbound Floriston offramp on I-80 east of Truckee
properties.Description: Established in 1872 as Bronco, this railroad wood stop became a noted ice and lumber center and was renamed in 1891. The Floriston Pulp and Paper Company built the present town after 1899 and operated one of the worldÍs largest pulp mills through 1930. Its paper products and ice helped California’s agricultural industry feed the hungry of the world. Note: Drive through culvert tunnel to get to town, which still has the feel of a company town.
